chunks.original_text: 金形属阴，故坚而重浊，金既属阴形，坚而重浊，自然下沉於地也，故云金坚故重浊，重浊者入地也。 轻清者，魄从魂升，重浊者，魂从魄降。 人修众善则属阳，死则善福所资，则其气轻清，自然魄从魂升於阳界，此亦自然之类也，故云轻清者，魄从魂升也。 人行众恶则属阴，死则恶业所摄，则其气重浊，自然魂从魄降，下沉於阴界，亦自然之类也，故云重浊者，魂从魄降也。 有以仁升者为木星佐，有以义升者为金星佐，有以礼升者为火星佐，有以智升者为水星佐，有以信升者为土星佐。 人专一行仁惠，行之至也，死而上升为木岁星之辅佐也，为仁属木也，亦自然而然各从其类也，故云有以仁升者为木星佐也。 人专行义以宜物，行之至也，死而上升为金太白星之辅佐也，为义属金也，故云有以义升为金星佐也。 人专行礼以尊君父，行之至也，死而上升为火荧惑星之辅佐也，为礼属火也，故云有以礼升者为火星佐也。 人专以智别真伪是非，从真是而不从伪，行之至也，死而上升为水极星之辅佐也，为智属水也，故云有以智升者为水星佐也。 人专行诚信，言行相符，行之至也，死而上升为土镇星之辅佐也，为信属土也，故云有以信升者为土星佐也。 有以不仁沉者木贼之，不义沉者金贼之，不礼沉者火贼之，不智沉者水贼之，不信沉者土贼之。 人行不仁，则众恶独擅，行之至也，则死而沉於阴界，则束岳拘而治罪，为束岳属木，既拘而治罪，非木贼而何，故云有以不仁况者木贼之也。 人专行不义，一切颠倒，不合义理，行之至也，则死而沉於阴界，则西岳拘而治罪，为西岳属金也，故云有以不义沉者金贼之也。 人专行无礼，侮慢君父，不忠不孝，行之至也，则死而沉於阴界，则南岳拘而治罪，为南岳属火，故云有以不礼沉者火贼之也。 人专行不智，愚痴所障，不鉴真伪是非，一切倒错，则死而沉於阴界，则北岳拘而治罪，为北岳属水也，故云有以不智沉者水贼之也。 人专行不诚，信一切诳言妄语，言行相违，诳妄过重，则死而况於阴界，则中岳拘而治罪，为中岳属土也，故云有以不信况者土贼之也。 已上行五常之德，则为五星之佐，背五常之德者，反彼#8五行贼之，可不慎欤！ 魂魄半之，则在人问， 人行半善半恶，则罪福两停，善属阳魂，恶属阴魄，如此则不升阳界，不沉阴界，只在人问宛转生死也，故云魂魄半之，则在人问。 升魂为贵，降魄为贱，灵魂为贤，厉魄为愚，轻魂为明，重魄为暗。 前生作善多，则升魂为今生富贵，故云升魂为贵也。 前生作恶多，则降魄为今生责贱之人也，故云降魄为贱也。 前生有慧，明理，则灵魂为今生贤人也，故云灵魂为贤也。 前生无慧，愚痴刚悍，则厉魄为今生愚人也，故云厉魄为愚也。 前生智性为善，则轻魂为今生聪明人也，故云轻魂为明也。 前生无智性为恶，则重魄为今生痴暗也，故云重魄为暗。 阳魂为羽，钝魄为毛，明魂为神，幽魄为鬼。 今生轻薄作恶，死而阳魂为羽虫之类，故阳魂为羽也。 今生痴钝作恶，死而钝魄为毛虫之类，故钝魄为毛也。 今生聪明正直，疾恶乐善，死而明魂为神只也，故明魂为神也。 今生好幽暗，行奸盗，作诸不善，死而幽魄为鬼也，故幽魄为鬼也。
chunks.translated_text:
Metal’s form pertains to yin, thus it is hard and heavy-turbid. Since metal’s form pertains to yin, being hard and heavy-turbid, it naturally sinks into the earth—hence it is said: *Metal is hard, thus heavy-turbid; what is heavy-turbid descends into the earth.*

What is light and pure: the *po* ascends following the *hun*. What is heavy and turbid: the *hun* descends following the *po*. When one cultivates all virtues, one pertains to yang; at death, the blessings of goodness sustain them, so their *qi* is light and pure, and the *po* naturally ascends with the *hun* into the yang realm—this, too, is a matter of natural correspondence. Hence it is said: *What is light and pure: the po ascends following the hun.*

When one commits all evils, one pertains to yin; at death, the karmic weight of wickedness seizes them, so their *qi* is heavy and turbid, and the *hun* naturally descends with the *po*, sinking into the yin realm—this, too, is a matter of natural correspondence. Hence it is said: *What is heavy and turbid: the hun descends following the po.*

Those who ascend through benevolence become assistants to Jupiter; those who ascend through righteousness become assistants to Venus; those who ascend through propriety become assistants to Mars; those who ascend through wisdom become assistants to Mercury; those who ascend through sincerity become assistants to Saturn.

One who devotes themselves entirely to benevolence and perfects its practice, at death ascends to become an assistant to Jupiter, the Year Star—for benevolence pertains to wood. This, too, follows naturally from its kind. Hence it is said: *Those who ascend through benevolence become assistants to Jupiter.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to righteousness and rightly orders all things, perfecting its practice, at death ascends to become an assistant to Venus, the Great White Star—for righteousness pertains to metal. Hence it is said: *Those who ascend through righteousness become assistants to Venus.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to propriety and honors ruler and father, perfecting its practice, at death ascends to become an assistant to Mars, the Sparkling Deluder—for propriety pertains to fire. Hence it is said: *Those who ascend through propriety become assistants to Mars.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to wisdom, discerning truth from falsehood and right from wrong, following truth and rejecting falsehood, perfecting its practice, at death ascends to become an assistant to Mercury, the Culminating Star—for wisdom pertains to water. Hence it is said: *Those who ascend through wisdom become assistants to Mercury.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to sincerity, aligning word with deed, perfecting its practice, at death ascends to become an assistant to Saturn, the Quelling Star—for sincerity pertains to earth. Hence it is said: *Those who ascend through sincerity become assistants to Saturn.*

Those who sink through lack of benevolence are punished by wood; those who sink through lack of righteousness are punished by metal; those who sink through lack of propriety are punished by fire; those who sink through lack of wisdom are punished by water; those who sink through lack of sincerity are punished by earth.

One who practices no benevolence, monopolizing all evils and perfecting their practice, at death sinks into the yin realm, where the Eastern Marchmount seizes and punishes them—for the Eastern Marchmount pertains to wood. If they are seized and punished, how is this not the predation of wood? Hence it is said: *Those who sink through lack of benevolence are punished by wood.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to unrighteousness, inverting all things and defying principle, perfecting their practice, at death sinks into the yin realm, where the Western Marchmount seizes and punishes them—for the Western Marchmount pertains to metal. Hence it is said: *Those who sink through lack of righteousness are punished by metal.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to impropriety, insulting ruler and father, disloyal and unfilial, perfecting their practice, at death sinks into the yin realm, where the Southern Marchmount seizes and punishes them—for the Southern Marchmount pertains to fire. Hence it is said: *Those who sink through lack of propriety are punished by fire.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to folly, deluded and obstructed, unable to discern truth from falsehood or right from wrong, inverting all things, at death sinks into the yin realm, where the Northern Marchmount seizes and punishes them—for the Northern Marchmount pertains to water. Hence it is said: *Those who sink through lack of wisdom are punished by water.*

One who devotes themselves entirely to insincerity, believing all deceitful words and lies, aligning neither word nor deed, their deceit and falsehood excessive, at death sinks into the yin realm, where the Central Marchmount seizes and punishes them—for the Central Marchmount pertains to earth. Hence it is said: *Those who sink through lack of sincerity are punished by earth.*

Those who perfect the virtues of the Five Constants become assistants to the Five Stars; those who betray the virtues of the Five Constants are, in turn, preyed upon by the Five Phases. How can one not be cautious!

When *hun* and *po* are evenly matched, one remains among humans.
One who practices both good and evil in equal measure has blessings and sins balanced: goodness pertains to the yang *hun*, evil to the yin *po*. Thus, they neither ascend to the yang realm nor sink into the yin realm, but remain among humans, revolving through birth and death. Hence it is said: *When hun and po are evenly matched, one remains among humans.*

The ascending *hun* brings nobility; the descending *po* brings baseness. The numinous *hun* brings worthiness; the malevolent *po* brings foolishness. The light *hun* brings brightness; the heavy *po* brings darkness.

If one performed many good deeds in a past life, the ascending *hun* brings wealth and nobility in this life. Hence it is said: *The ascending hun brings nobility.*

If one performed many evil deeds in a past life, the descending *po* brings poverty and baseness in this life. Hence it is said: *The descending po brings baseness.*

If one possessed wisdom and understood principle in a past life, the numinous *hun* brings worthiness in this life. Hence it is said: *The numinous hun brings worthiness.*

If one lacked wisdom in a past life, being foolish, obstinate, and violent, the malevolent *po* brings foolishness in this life. Hence it is said: *The malevolent po brings foolishness.*

If one cultivated wisdom and goodness in a past life, the light *hun* brings intelligence in this life. Hence it is said: *The light hun brings brightness.*

If one lacked wisdom and practiced evil in a past life, the heavy *po* brings dullness and darkness in this life. Hence it is said: *The heavy po brings darkness.*

The yang *hun* becomes winged creatures; the dull *po* becomes furred creatures. The luminous *hun* becomes spirits; the obscure *po* becomes ghosts.

If one was frivolous and committed evil in this life, at death the yang *hun* becomes a creature with wings. Hence it is said: *The yang hun becomes winged creatures.*

If one was dull and committed evil in this life, at death the dull *po* becomes a creature with fur. Hence it is said: *The dull po becomes furred creatures.*

If one was intelligent, upright, detested evil, and delighted in goodness in this life, at death the luminous *hun* becomes a spirit. Hence it is said: *The luminous hun becomes spirits.*

If one favored darkness, practiced deceit and theft, and committed all manner of evil in this life, at death the obscure *po* becomes a ghost. Hence it is said: *The obscure po becomes ghosts.*

chunks.original_text: 其形其居，其识其好，皆以五行契之。 贵贱贤愚，明暗羽毛神鬼，其形状居处虽不同，皆因业识所好之因，各报如此之果也。 如好五常之因，得报为五星卿佐之果也，如违五常之因，报有五岳治罪之果也，故云其形其居，其识其好，皆以五行契之。 惟行之数#9，参差不一，所以万物之多，盈天地问犹未已也。 水生数一，成数六，火生数二，成数七，木生数三，成数八，金生数四，成数九，土生数五，成数十，故云惟行之数#10，参差不一也。 五行阴阳，相推相荡，交感变化，巨细洪纤，飞潜动植，所以纷纷扰扰不止，於万亿之多，充盈於天地之问，生生化化，感异类创生，犹未止息也，故云所以万物之多，盈天地问犹未已也。 以五事归五行，以五行作五虫，可胜言哉。 以事者，皆用也，五用者，视听食息思。 归五行者，目乃肝之外表，肝属木，故目视属木也，耳乃肾之外表，肾属水，耳听属水也，舌乃心之外表，心属火，故舌食属火也，鼻乃肺之外表，肺属金，故鼻息属金也，意乃脾之神，属土，故意思属土也。 故云以五事归五行也。 五行者，木火土金水也。 五虫者，鳞羽保毛甲也，东方甲乙木，作鳞虫三百六十种，龙为长也，南方丙丁火，作羽虫三百六十种，凤凰为长也，中央戊己土，保虫三百六十种，圣人为长也，西方庚辛金，作毛虫三百六十种，麒麟为长也，北方壬癸水，作甲虫三百六十种，灵龟为长也，故云以五行作五虫，可任论动植之物也，故云可胜言哉也。 胜者，任也，言者，论也。 譬如兆龟数曹，至诚自契，五行应之，诚苟不至，兆之数之，无一应者。

Their forms and dwellings, their perceptions and preferences—all are bound to the Five Phases. Whether noble or base, wise or foolish, luminous or obscure, winged or furred, spirits or ghosts, though their shapes and abodes differ, all arise from the karmic seeds of their perceptions and desires, each reaping its corresponding fruit. Those who cultivate the Five Constants as their cause receive the fruit of becoming the five celestial ministers; those who violate the Five Constants receive the fruit of being judged by the Five Peaks. Hence it is said: *Their forms and dwellings, their perceptions and preferences—all are bound to the Five Phases.*

The generative and consummate numbers of the Phases are not uniform, which is why the myriad things are so abundant that they fill the space between Heaven and Earth without cease. Water’s generative number is one, its consummate number six; fire’s generative number is two, its consummate number seven; wood’s generative number is three, its consummate number eight; metal’s generative number is four, its consummate number nine; earth’s generative number is five, its consummate number ten. Hence it is said: *The numbers of the Phases are not uniform.*

The Five Phases and yin-yang mutually impel and agitate, intermingling and transforming. From the vast to the minute, the flying and the hidden, the moving and the still—all teem and surge without end. In their countless multitudes, they fill the space between Heaven and Earth, ceaselessly generating and transforming, giving rise to diverse kinds, never resting. Hence it is said: *This is why the myriad things are so abundant that they fill the space between Heaven and Earth without cease.*

The Five Affairs correspond to the Five Phases, and the Five Phases give rise to the Five Creatures—how could one exhaust their enumeration? The Five Affairs are all functions: seeing, hearing, eating, breathing, and thinking. Their correspondence to the Five Phases is as follows: the eyes are the outward manifestation of the liver, and the liver belongs to wood, so seeing pertains to wood; the ears are the outward manifestation of the kidneys, and the kidneys belong to water, so hearing pertains to water; the tongue is the outward manifestation of the heart, and the heart belongs to fire, so eating pertains to fire; the nose is the outward manifestation of the lungs, and the lungs belong to metal, so breathing pertains to metal; the mind is the spirit of the spleen, and the spleen belongs to earth, so thinking pertains to earth. Hence it is said: *The Five Affairs correspond to the Five Phases.*

The Five Phases are wood, fire, earth, metal, and water. The Five Creatures are scaled, feathered, naked, furred, and armored. The east, with its celestial stems *jia* and *yi*, belongs to wood and gives rise to 360 kinds of scaled creatures, with the dragon as their chief. The south, with its celestial stems *bing* and *ding*, belongs to fire and gives rise to 360 kinds of feathered creatures, with the phoenix as their chief. The center, with its celestial stems *wu* and *ji*, belongs to earth and gives rise to 360 kinds of naked creatures, with the sage as their chief. The west, with its celestial stems *geng* and *xin*, belongs to metal and gives rise to 360 kinds of furred creatures, with the qilin as their chief. The north, with its celestial stems *ren* and *gui*, belongs to water and gives rise to 360 kinds of armored creatures, with the spirit-turtle as their chief. Hence it is said: *The Five Phases give rise to the Five Creatures*—how could one exhaust the discussion of moving and growing things? *Sheng* means "to bear," and *yan* means "to discourse."

For example, when divining with tortoise shells or milfoil stalks, if sincerity is fully present, the Five Phases respond; but if sincerity is lacking, no matter how one divines or calculates, not a single response will come.

chunks.original_text: 兆龟数着，见解二柱首章也。 向来所说贵贱贤愚明暗羽毛神鬼五常之因果，譬如以至诚祝愿钻龟毂数着草，五行应之以吉凶之兆也，人之其形其居其识其好，皆以五行契之，亦复如是也，故云譬如兆龟数着，至诚自契，五行应之也。 若钻龟数着之时，而心不至诚，士凶之兆无一应也。 人心无所爱着，绝其所好，清净无染，离种种边，不落因果，轮回亦复如是也，故云诚苟不至，兆之数之，无一应者也。 圣人假物以游世，五行不得不对。 圣人假借四大之貌物，以五常之德，普利韦品，为之妙用也。 既以五常为妙用，寓游世间，普利韦品，以仁属木，义属金，礼属火，智属水，信属土，既为之五常，不得不对属於五行也。 故云圣人假物以游世，五行不得不对也。 此章明心有染着，则落因果，心离染着，则出轮回。 右第六章 关尹子曰：三者具有魂，魂者识，目者精，色者神，见之者，为魂耳口鼻心之类。 魂具此识精神，三也，故云三者具有魂也。 魂昼寓目，目视而辫五色，亦具识精神，然后能视辫之也，故云魂者识，目者精，色者神也，谓目之辫色者，魂识也，目之神水乃精神也。 不独视为然，耳听声，口尝味，鼻闻香，心思境，皆同具有识精神，方能别辩声味香境也，故云见之者，为魂耳口鼻心之类也。 类者同也。 在此生者，爱为精，为彼生父本，观为神，为彼生母本，爱观虽异，皆同识生。 在此生身者，为彼父，生爱识恋母爱为精，精属水，彼母生观识恋父，观为神，神属火，父母交感精神，为此生身之本也，故云在此生者，爱为精，为彼生父本，观为神，为彼生母本，父母爱观虽不同，皆用识情交感生子则同也，故云爱观虽异，皆因同生也#11。 彼生生本。 在彼生者，一为父，故受气於父气，为水，二为母，故受血於母血为火， 彼父母，生生之本也，为父精属水，水数一，故一为父也，此身受生之初，先得父之精气以成胎元，精气属水，故云彼生生本，在彼生者，一为父，故受气於父气，为水也； 为母血属火，火数二，故二为母也。 此身受生之初，次得母之血气以成胎本，血气属火，故云二为母，故受血於母血，为火。 有父有母，彼生生矣。 有父有母，阴阳交感，彼为父父母母，而生生不穷矣，故云有父有母，彼生生矣。 惟其爱之无识，如锁之交，观之无识，如灯之照，吾识不萌，吾生何有。 惟以至弁不仁，平等普利而无识，不求报恩，不住行仁之迹，虽与世交，如锁绩相交，而无情识之心也，故云惟其爱之无识，如锁之交也。 仁者兼爱也，圆明定慧，如大圆镜，镒物无心，如灯破暗，照物无识也，故云观之无识，如灯之照也。 如上所说，至也不七，平等普利而无心，定慧圆明，应物而无识，吾识不萌生，吾生死何有哉，故云吾识不萌，吾生何有哉。 此章明识是生死之种，无识则无生死轮回也。 右第七章 关尹子曰：如杆扣鼓，鼓之形者，我之有也，鼓之声者，我之感也，杆已往矣，余声尚存，终亦不存而已矣。 寓游於世，物来相感，如似拌槌扣击於鼓，感而后声也，故云如杆扣鼓也。 我之所有精神，如鼓之形，我之应感，如鼓之声也，故云鼓之形者，我之有也，鼓之声者，我之感也，标槌已往，鼓余声尚在。

The divination with tortoise shells and milfoil stalks is the second chapter of the "Two Pillars of Interpretation." All that has been discussed earlier—nobility and baseness, wisdom and foolishness, clarity and obscurity, feathered and furred creatures, spirits and ghosts, and the karmic causes of the Five Constants—is like making sincere prayers and drilling the tortoise shell or casting the milfoil stalks: the Five Phases respond with auspicious or inauspicious omens. A person’s form, dwelling, knowledge, and preferences all correspond to the Five Phases in the same way. Thus it is said: *For example, when divining with tortoise shells or milfoil stalks, if sincerity is fully present, the Five Phases respond.*

If, when drilling the tortoise shell or casting the milfoil stalks, the heart is not fully sincere, not a single omen of fortune or misfortune will respond. When the human heart has no attachments, severs its desires, remains pure and unstained, departs from all extremes, and does not fall into cause and effect, the cycle of rebirth is likewise. Thus it is said: *If sincerity is lacking, no matter how one divines or calculates, not a single response will come.*

The sage borrows things to wander through the world, and the Five Phases cannot but correspond. The sage employs the forms of the Four Great Elements and the virtue of the Five Constants to universally benefit all beings, making wondrous use of them. Having taken the Five Constants as their wondrous function, dwelling and wandering in the world to universally benefit all beings, they assign benevolence to wood, righteousness to metal, propriety to fire, wisdom to water, and trustworthiness to earth. Since these are the Five Constants, they cannot but correspond to the Five Phases. Thus it is said: *The sage borrows things to wander through the world, and the Five Phases cannot but correspond.*

This chapter clarifies that when the heart is stained with attachments, it falls into cause and effect; when the heart is free from attachments, it escapes the cycle of rebirth.

**Chapter Six**
Master Guan Yin said: The three possess the *hun*-soul. The *hun* is consciousness; the eye is essence; color is spirit. That which perceives them belongs to the *hun*—ears, mouth, nose, heart, and the like.

The *hun* possesses this consciousness, essence, and spirit—these three. Thus it is said: *The three possess the *hun*-soul.* The *hun* dwells in the eye by day; the eye sees and distinguishes the five colors. It also possesses consciousness, essence, and spirit, and only then can it see and distinguish. Thus it is said: *The *hun* is consciousness; the eye is essence; color is spirit.* That which distinguishes color with the eye is the *hun*’s consciousness; the eye’s spirit-water is its essence and spirit.

Not only is seeing so, but hearing sounds, tasting flavors, smelling fragrances, and the heart contemplating objects all similarly possess consciousness, essence, and spirit before they can distinguish sounds, flavors, fragrances, and objects. Thus it is said: *That which perceives them belongs to the *hun*—ears, mouth, nose, heart, and the like.* "The like" means "the same."

In this life, love is essence and the root of the father for the next life; observation is spirit and the root of the mother for the next life. Though love and observation differ, both arise from the same consciousness. In this life, the body is the father for the next; the love that clings to the mother is essence—essence belongs to water. The mother for the next life is the observation that clings to the father—observation is spirit, and spirit belongs to fire. The intermingling of the father’s and mother’s essence and spirit is the root of this life’s body. Thus it is said: *In this life, love is essence and the root of the father for the next life; observation is spirit and the root of the mother for the next life.* Though the father’s love and the mother’s observation differ, both use consciousness and emotion to intermingle and give birth to the child—they are the same. Thus it is said: *Though love and observation differ, both arise from the same cause.*

The root of the next life’s birth. In the next life, the first is the father, so one receives *qi* from the father’s *qi*, which is water. The second is the mother, so one receives blood from the mother’s blood, which is fire. The father and mother of the next life are the root of its birth. The father’s essence belongs to water, and water’s number is one—thus the first is the father. At the beginning of this body’s birth, it first receives the father’s essence-*qi* to form the embryo’s origin—essence-*qi* belongs to water. Thus it is said: *The root of the next life’s birth. In the next life, the first is the father, so one receives *qi* from the father’s *qi*, which is water.* The mother’s blood belongs to fire, and fire’s number is two—thus the second is the mother. At the beginning of this body’s birth, it next receives the mother’s blood-*qi* to form the embryo’s foundation—blood-*qi* belongs to fire. Thus it is said: *The second is the mother, so one receives blood from the mother’s blood, which is fire.* With a father and a mother, the next life is born. With a father and a mother, yin and yang intermingle, and the father and mother of the next life give birth without end. Thus it is said: *With a father and a mother, the next life is born.*

Only when love is without consciousness, like the intertwining of a lock, and observation is without consciousness, like the illumination of a lamp—when my consciousness does not sprout—how can my birth exist? Only by being perfectly impartial, universally benefiting all without consciousness, seeking no reward, and not abiding in the traces of benevolent action—though engaging with the world like the intertwining of a lock’s rings, without the heart of emotional consciousness—can this be so. Thus it is said: *Only when love is without consciousness, like the intertwining of a lock.* The benevolent embrace all with love; their perfect clarity, concentration, and wisdom are like a great mirror, reflecting things without heart, like a lamp dispelling darkness, illuminating things without consciousness. Thus it is said: *Observation is without consciousness, like the illumination of a lamp.* As described above, being perfectly impartial, universally benefiting all without heart, with concentration and wisdom perfectly clear, responding to things without consciousness—when my consciousness does not sprout, how can my birth and death exist? Thus it is said: *When my consciousness does not sprout, how can my birth exist?* This chapter clarifies that consciousness is the seed of birth and death; without consciousness, there is no cycle of birth and death.

**Chapter Seven**
Master Guan Yin said: It is like striking a drum with a stick. The drum’s form is what I possess; the drum’s sound is my response. The stick has already gone, yet the lingering sound remains—ultimately, it too will cease to exist.

Wandering through the world, when things come to interact, it is like a drumstick striking a drum—only after being struck does the sound arise. Thus it is said: *It is like striking a drum with a stick.* What I possess—my essence and spirit—is like the drum’s form; my response is like the drum’s sound. Thus it is said: *The drum’s form is what I possess; the drum’s sound is my response.* The stick has already gone, yet the drum’s lingering sound remains.

chunks.original_text: 如感我者已往，我之精神魂魄之识，尚未能忘，回光照破此识而忘之，是终亦不存也，故云标已往矣，余声尚存，终亦不存而已矣。 鼓之形如我之精，鼓之声如我之神，其余声者，犹之魂魄。 吾之历历精明，如鼓之形也，吾之寂然不动，感而遂通，如鼓之声也，故云鼓之形如我之精，鼓之声如我之神也。 吾之魂魄之识，物感不忘，犹似标已往矣，鼓之余声尚存也。 故云余声者，犹魂魄也。 知夫倏往倏来，则五行之气我何有哉。 人能了悟本性真空，物境倏忽来往，应变常寂，如此，金木水火土五行之气，於真空何有哉。 故云知夫倏往倏来，则五行之气我何有哉。 此章明真空不属五行也。 右第八章 关尹子曰：夫果之有核，必待水火土三者具矣，然后相生不穷，三者不具，如大旱大僚大块，皆不足以生物。 果木之中，有子核埋於土内，铃待雨阴水之滋润，晴阳火之熏蒸，然后核生芽，芽长成树，树复结果核，核依前种之，水火土三者滋润熏蒸，复生芽长树结果核，相生无有尽期也。 故云夫果之有核，铃待水火土三者具矣，然后相生不穷也，若果核不埋於土，无阴雨阳晴滋润熏蒸，安能生芽成树哉，若无水火土，如似大亢旱时，大水沸时，大乾土块时，三时种物皆不得生也。 故云三者不具，如大旱大潦大块，皆不足以生物也。 潦者，满也，足者，得也。 精水神火意土三者本不交，惟人以根合之，故能於其中横见有事。 精属水，神属火，意属土，精神意三者本不交生於物，惟人之父母，以二根交合，精神意识混融於恍惚之际，横妄见其象有此胞胎之事，生生不穷，如果核得水火土，生芽长树复结果核，生生不穷也。 故云精水神火意土三者本不交，惟人以根合之，故能於其中横见有事也。 犹如卫呎，能於至无见多有事。 父母未交合之时，各自真空之性，本来清静无物，以二根交合，精神意而生子者，犹法衍呢士巫现之类，能於至无中呼召鬼神，妄见变化怪异之事也，故云犹如衍呢，能於至无见多有事也。 此章明本来清静，元无生死，人迷爱欲，屈沉生死也。 右第九章 关尹子曰：魂者水也#12，木根於冬水，而花於夏火，故人之魂藏於夜精，而见於昼神。 魂者，木也，木冬时归根复命，得冬水熙滋养，於夏得火黑熏蒸，则发花也，故云魂者木也，木根於冬水，而华於夏火也。 精属水，魂属木，水生木，故云人之魂藏於夜精也，夜属阴，阴属水，昼属阳，阳属火，神属火，魂昼寓目以见神彩，故云而见於昼神也。 合乎精，故所见我独，盖精未尝有人，合乎神，故所见人同，盖神未尝有我。 精属水，水无人也，精亦无人也，合乎至精，则历历孤明，不与万法为倡也，故云合乎精，故所见我独。 盖精无人也，合乎至神，则冥冥莫测，感而后应，应人事而无我也，神属火，火无我，神亦无我也，故云合乎神，故所见人同，盖神未尝有我也。 此章明全乎至精至神者，无人我也。 右第十章 关尹子曰：知夫此身如梦中身，随情所见者，可以飞神作我而游太清， 知者，悟也，人能了悟四大假合之身，如尘埃聚沬、浮涯梦幻不坚固，虚妄不实之身，皆是随妄情所见，以为有我，了悟如此，洞彻真空，以飞腾神用不疾而速，不行而至，太清之境无日不游也。

As the stimulus that aroused me has already passed, yet the awareness of my essence, spirit, soul, and vitality lingers unresolved—turning the light inward to shatter this awareness and forget it is what ultimately renders it nonexistent. Thus it is said: *The stick has already gone, yet the lingering sound remains—ultimately, it too will cease to exist.* The drum’s form is like my essence; the drum’s sound is like my spirit; its lingering resonance is like my soul and vitality.

My vivid clarity is like the drum’s form; my stillness, unmoving, yet responsive and all-pervading, is like the drum’s sound. Thus it is said: *The drum’s form is like my essence; the drum’s sound is like my spirit.* The awareness of my soul and vitality, unceasing in its response to external stimuli, is like the stick that has already gone, yet the drum’s lingering resonance remains. Thus it is said: *The lingering sound is like the soul and vitality.*

Know that what comes and goes in an instant—how can the qi of the Five Phases belong to me? If one awakens to the true emptiness of original nature, perceiving the fleeting comings and goings of external phenomena while remaining ever still in response, then how can the qi of Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth pertain to true emptiness? Thus it is said: *Know that what comes and goes in an instant—how can the qi of the Five Phases belong to me?* This chapter clarifies that true emptiness does not pertain to the Five Phases.

**Chapter Eight**
Master Guan Yin said: The kernel within a fruit must await the presence of Water, Fire, and Earth—only then can it generate endlessly. Without all three, as in great drought, great flood, or barren clods, none suffice to bring forth life.

Within the fruit, the kernel buried in the soil must await the nourishment of rain and moisture, the warmth of sunlight and fire—only then does the kernel sprout, the sprout grow into a tree, and the tree bear fruit once more. The kernel is planted again, and with the nurturing warmth of Water, Fire, and Earth, it sprouts, grows into a tree, and bears fruit in an unending cycle. Thus it is said: *The kernel within a fruit must await the presence of Water, Fire, and Earth—only then can it generate endlessly.*

If the kernel is not buried in soil, lacking the nourishment of rain and sunlight, how can it sprout and grow into a tree? Without Water, Fire, and Earth, as in times of severe drought, flooding, or parched earth, nothing can take root and grow. Thus it is said: *Without all three, as in great drought, great flood, or barren clods, none suffice to bring forth life.* "Flood" means excess; "suffice" means attainment.

Essence-Water, Spirit-Fire, and Mind-Earth do not originally interact—only when humans unite them through the root do they appear to give rise to phenomena. Essence pertains to Water, Spirit to Fire, and Mind to Earth. These three—essence, spirit, and mind—do not inherently generate phenomena, but when a man and woman unite their roots, essence, spirit, and awareness merge in the fleeting moment of conception, illusorily perceiving the form of this embryonic event. Thus life arises endlessly, just as a kernel, with Water, Fire, and Earth, sprouts, grows into a tree, and bears fruit in an unceasing cycle. Thus it is said: *Essence-Water, Spirit-Fire, and Mind-Earth do not originally interact—only when humans unite them through the root do they appear to give rise to phenomena.*

It is like a sorcerer who, from utter nothingness, conjures manifold phenomena. Before the union of man and woman, each abides in the true emptiness of original nature, fundamentally pure and devoid of phenomena. Yet through the union of their roots, essence, spirit, and mind give rise to a child—much like a sorcerer or shaman who, from utter nothingness, summons spirits and illusorily perceives strange transformations. Thus it is said: *It is like a sorcerer who, from utter nothingness, conjures manifold phenomena.* This chapter clarifies that originally, all is pure and still, fundamentally free from birth and death. It is human delusion and desire that plunge one into the cycle of birth and death.

**Chapter Nine**
Master Guan Yin said: The soul is Water; the root of Wood lies in winter Water, yet its blossoms appear in summer Fire. Thus, a person’s soul is stored in the night’s essence and manifests in the day’s spirit.

The soul is Wood. In winter, Wood returns to its root to renew its life, nourished by winter Water; in summer, warmed by Fire, it blooms. Thus it is said: *The soul is Wood; the root of Wood lies in winter Water, yet its blossoms appear in summer Fire.* Essence pertains to Water, and the soul to Wood—Water generates Wood. Thus it is said: *A person’s soul is stored in the night’s essence.* Night pertains to yin, and yin to Water; day pertains to yang, and yang to Fire. The spirit pertains to Fire, and the soul, dwelling in the eyes by day, reveals its radiance through the spirit. Thus it is said: *And manifests in the day’s spirit.*

United with essence, what is perceived is uniquely mine—for essence has never known another. United with spirit, what is perceived is shared by all—for spirit has never known a self. Essence pertains to Water, and Water has no other; thus, essence also has no other. United with pure essence, one’s clarity stands solitary, unaccompanied by the myriad phenomena. Thus it is said: *United with essence, what is perceived is uniquely mine—for essence has never known another.* United with pure spirit, one’s awareness is profound and unfathomable, responsive only after being stirred, answering to others without a self. Spirit pertains to Fire, and Fire has no self; thus, spirit also has no self. Thus it is said: *United with spirit, what is perceived is shared by all—for spirit has never known a self.* This chapter clarifies that one who embodies pure essence and pure spirit transcends both self and other.

**Chapter Ten**
Master Guan Yin said: Realize that this body is like a body in a dream, appearing as one’s emotions dictate—then one may send forth the spirit as oneself and wander the Great Purity.

To "realize" is to awaken. If one awakens to the truth that this body, composed of the four great elements, is like dust gathering into foam—ephemeral, dreamlike, and insubstantial—an illusory and unreal form shaped by deluded emotions into the notion of a self, then, with such awakening and thorough penetration of true emptiness, one may soar with the spirit’s function, swift without haste, arriving without traveling, and wander the realm of the Great Purity without cease.

chunks.original_text: 太清者，真空之妙道也，故云知夫此身如梦中身，随情所见者，可以飞神作我而游太清也。 知夫此物如梦中物，随情所见者，可以凝精作物而驾八荒。 物者，用也，人能悟此六用神通，亦如梦幻不实，了悟知此，洞彻真空，以凝澄清精微之体，而作生妙用，驾驭八荒，而为顷刻之游也，故云知夫此物如梦中物，随情所见者，可以凝精作物而驾八荒也。 八荒者，四海之外谓之八弦，八弦之外谓之八演，八演之外谓之八区，八区之外谓之八极，八极之外谓之八荒，八荒之外谓之鸿荒，广莫之界也。 又太清者，太上所居之天也，在四种民天之上，即太清仙境也。 大开之士，以真空太虚为体，远及八荒之外，近在眉睫之问，阴阳莫测，鬼神难窥，不假他物，八荒之外太清仙境而为咫尺顷刻之游也。 或示变化警愚迷，启诚信向道之心，或以飞神作身外之身，而乘空履虚，升游太清仙境，或以凝精作龙虎鸾凤，龟鹤梁鲤箕楼之类，驾驭而适八荒之外，以为游戏也。 是道也，能见精神而久生，能忘精神而超生。 是者，此也，道者，不可思议之道也，了悟不可思议之妙道，则形如桔木，心似寒灰，自然神定精凝，返老还童延形，长生久视，如广成子千二百岁，身未尝衰是也。 故云是道也，能见精神而久生也。 既身心如桔木寒灰，即是以忘精神，而远超生灭也，故云能忘精神而超生也。 吸气以养精，如金生水， 气白色属金，世有卫生小功法，以鼻吸气在息须突，微微缓出，以为养精攻病，以气养滋其精，如金生水，为气属金，精属水也，故云吸气以养精，如金生水也。 吸风以养神，如木生火， 世有小功法以治心者，以鼻引清风，微微来往出入，则心不乱而神定，亦得其所养，如木生火，为风属木，神属火也，放云吸风以养神，故木生火也。 所以假外以延精神。 如上所说，吸气吸风以养精神，是假外以延留精神，不令耗散也，故云所以假外以延精神也。 漱水以养精，精之所以不穷， 世有小功法，以漱津液而保养其精，不令走泄，而精益无穷也，故云漱水以养精，精之所以不穷也。 摩火以养神，神之所以不穷， 世有小功法，凝思以手摩脐轮，令热如火，久而神益无穷也，故云摩火以养神，神之所以不穷也。 所以假内以延精神。 如上所说，漱津液之水，摩脐轮之火，不假外物，是假内以延留精神，不令耗散也，故云所以假内以延精神也。 若夫忘精#13而超生者，吾尝言之矣。 若夫洞了真空，精神返源，窈冥莫测，不知有精神之可忘，亦无生灭之可超，吾尝垂示学人言之矣，其他假外假内小功小法，吾未尝言之也，故云若夫忘精神而超生者，吾尝言之矣。 此章明道由心悟，而行小功小法莫之及也。 右第十一章 关尹子曰：人勤於礼者，神不外驰，可以集神， 礼在五行属火，神亦属火，礼者，谨敬也，人心专以护敬慎独，不欺合室，则心神不驰骋，而凝集静定也，故云人动於礼者，神不外驰，可以集神也。 馑者专也。 人勤於智者，精不外移，可以摄精。 智在五行属水，精亦属水，智者，明真伪是非，专以保真忘伪，则名从是违非也，如此则精不妄泄於外，可以摄养至精也，故云人动於智者，精不外移，可以摄精也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Great Purity is the wondrous Dao of true emptiness—thus it is said: "Realize that this body is like a body in a dream, appearing as one’s emotions dictate, then one may send forth the spirit as oneself and wander the Great Purity." Realize that these phenomena are like objects in a dream, shaped by one’s emotions—then one may condense essence into phenomena and traverse the Eight Wastes.

Phenomena are functions. If one awakens to the sixfold spiritual penetrations as likewise dreamlike and insubstantial, and thoroughly penetrates true emptiness, one may concentrate the luminous clarity of refined essence to manifest wondrous function, riding the Eight Wastes in an instant’s journey. Thus it is said: "Realize that these phenomena are like objects in a dream, appearing as one’s emotions dictate, then one may condense essence into phenomena and traverse the Eight Wastes."

The Eight Wastes lie beyond the Four Seas, called the Eight Chords; beyond the Eight Chords lie the Eight Expanses; beyond the Eight Expanses lie the Eight Regions; beyond the Eight Regions lie the Eight Poles; beyond the Eight Poles lie the Eight Wastes; beyond the Eight Wastes lies the Vast Primeval, the boundless frontier.

Moreover, the Great Purity is the heaven where the Supreme resides, above the Four Celestial Realms of humankind—it is the immortal realm of the Great Purity. Those of great attainment take true emptiness and the Great Void as their body, reaching as far as beyond the Eight Wastes and as near as the space between their brows. Yin and yang cannot fathom it; ghosts and spirits cannot glimpse it. Without relying on external things, they traverse the immortal realm of the Great Purity beyond the Eight Wastes in an instant’s journey.

At times, they manifest transformations to awaken the deluded; at others, they rouse sincerity and faith in the Dao. Sometimes they project the spirit as a body beyond the body, riding the void and treading emptiness to ascend and wander the immortal realm of the Great Purity. At other times, they condense essence into dragons and tigers, simurghs and phoenixes, tortoises and cranes, beams and carp, winnowing baskets and towers, riding them to roam beyond the Eight Wastes in playful excursion.

This Dao can preserve spirit to prolong life, or forget spirit to transcend life. *This* refers to this Dao—the inconceivable Dao. When one awakens to the wondrousness of this inconceivable Dao, the body becomes like withered wood, the mind like cold ashes. Naturally, the spirit settles and essence congeals, reversing aging to restore youth, extending life and preserving vision—like Guangchengzi, who lived twelve hundred years without ever declining. Thus it is said: "This Dao can preserve spirit to prolong life." When body and mind are like withered wood and cold ashes, one forgets spirit and far transcends birth and death. Thus it is said: "It can forget spirit to transcend life."

Inhale qi to nourish essence, like metal generating water.
Qi is white and belongs to metal. There exists a minor practice of hygiene: inhaling through the nose, holding the breath briefly, and exhaling slowly to nourish essence and cure illness. Qi nurtures essence as metal generates water—qi pertains to metal, essence to water. Thus it is said: "Inhale qi to nourish essence, like metal generating water."

Inhale wind to nourish spirit, like wood generating fire.
There exists a minor practice to cultivate the heart: drawing in pure wind through the nose, allowing gentle ebb and flow, so the heart remains undisturbed and the spirit settled, thus receiving its nourishment. Wind pertains to wood, spirit to fire. Thus it is said: "Inhale wind to nourish spirit, like wood generating fire."

These methods borrow externals to extend spirit.
As mentioned above, inhaling qi and wind to nourish spirit borrows externals to retain and extend spirit, preventing its dissipation. Thus it is said: "These methods borrow externals to extend spirit."

Rinse with water to nourish essence, so essence never depletes.
There exists a minor practice: rinsing with saliva to preserve essence, preventing its leakage, so essence flourishes without end. Thus it is said: "Rinse with water to nourish essence, so essence never depletes."

Rub with fire to nourish spirit, so spirit never depletes.
There exists a minor practice: concentrating the mind to rub the navel wheel until it grows hot as fire, so spirit flourishes without end. Thus it is said: "Rub with fire to nourish spirit, so spirit never depletes."

These methods borrow internals to extend spirit.
As mentioned above, rinsing with the water of saliva and rubbing with the fire of the navel wheel do not rely on externals—they borrow internals to retain and extend spirit, preventing its dissipation. Thus it is said: "These methods borrow internals to extend spirit."

As for those who forget essence to transcend life, I have spoken of this before.
When one thoroughly penetrates true emptiness and spirit returns to its source, profound and unfathomable, one no longer knows of spirit to forget, nor of birth and death to transcend. I have often instructed disciples on this. As for other minor practices borrowing externals or internals, I have never spoken of them. Thus it is said: "As for those who forget essence to transcend life, I have spoken of this before."

This chapter clarifies that the Dao is realized through the awakening of the heart—minor practices cannot compare.

**Chapter Eleven**
Master Guan Yin said: One who diligently practices ritual keeps the spirit from scattering and may gather it.
Ritual pertains to fire in the Five Phases, as does spirit. Ritual is reverence and care. When the heart is devoted to vigilance and sincerity, never deceiving even in solitude, the spirit does not gallop outward but gathers and settles in stillness. Thus it is said: "One who diligently practices ritual keeps the spirit from scattering and may gather it." *Diligence* means focus.

One who diligently cultivates wisdom prevents essence from leaking and may refine it.
Wisdom pertains to water in the Five Phases, as does essence. Wisdom discerns truth from falsehood, right from wrong, and is devoted to preserving truth and forgetting falsehood—thus names follow right and shun wrong. In this way, essence does not leak outward but may be refined and nurtured. Thus it is said: "One who diligently cultivates wisdom prevents essence from leaking and may refine it."

chunks.original_text: 摄者，养也。 仁则阳而明，可以轻魂，义则阴而冥，可以御魄。 仁在五行属木，魂亦属木，仁以静自利，以慈利他，慈善属阳，静则明了，魂神轻清而澄湛也，故云化则阳而明，可以轻魂也。 义在五行属金，魄亦属金，洞了真空，与道相真，阴隐窈冥，令尸魄止静而澄彻也，故云义则阴而冥，可以御魄也。 御者，使止也。 此章明五常为道之妙用也。 右第十二章 关尹子曰：蜕．娘转丸，丸成，精思之，而有蚊白存丸中，俄去毂而蝉， 蜕娘推粪转为丸球，丸球既成，钻入土中，抱丸而精一思之，其蜕娘精神气俱入丸中，化为螟白虫，经秋冬春三诗气含养，得厦火气熏蒸，出土缘上草木墙壁之类，俄顷之问，从脊裂开，退去皮谷，化而为蝉，飞道林木，州妒吸风饮露而呜也。 故云蜕娘转丸，丸成，精思之而有螟白存丸中，俄去壳而为蝉也。 彼蜕不思，彼换奚白。 彼蜕娘不抱粪丸精思之，彼螟虫何得生白哉！ 皆因妄想，而形随之而变也，枚云彼蜕不思，彼烦美白也。 奚者，何也。 此章明生死变化，皆因妄想食着而有也。 右第十三章 关尹子曰：庖人羹螂，遗一足桃上，妩已羹，而遗足尚动，是生死者，一气聚散尔， 庖姗之人，将螃妩作叹之时，遗留螃螂一、卿足桃卓案上，其螃螂作成羹，而遣渎之脚淌自嚼动，以此知是生死者，一东冻散尔，气东则生，气散测界遗足尚励者，气未嗽尽也，牧云直人羹螂，遗一足桃上，螂已羹，而遗足尚动，是生死者，一气聚散尔。 不生不死，而人横计日生死。 横者，妄也，本来面目真空之性，弃不工自五太之前，五太之前未有一气，以此明知真空之性不属气也，不属气者，则无东做，无聚做者，则无生死也，如此则知不悟性者，但见气聚成形以为生，气散形坏以为死，岂不妄计哉，故云不生不死，而人横计曰生死也。 此章明性本无生死，迷人妄计而恐怖也。 右第十四章 关尹子曰：有死立者，有死坐者，有死外者，有死病者，有死药者，等死，无甲乙之殊。 世问或有人立地化去者，或有坐地化去者，或有声地化一法者，或有因病重化去者，或有因服毒药化去者，立坐卦病药五等之不同，其死则不异也，无甲死者如何、乙死者如何之殊异也。 故云有死立渚，有死坐者，有死外者，有死病者，有死药者，等死，无甲乙之殊也。 若知道之士，不见生，故不见死。 知者，悟也，悟道之士，洞了真空，心无生灭，反观四大假合，如尘埃东沬，如蓬庐质合暂寄而已，不见生死之可逃也，故云若知道之士，不见生，故不见死也。 此章明道无生死，了道者无生死之可见也。 右第十五章 关尹子曰：人之厌生死超生死者，皆是大患， 息者，病也，迷人不悟道无生死而能生死者，则一沐生不死也，未悟如此起厌生死之心，拟欲直超生死者，皆是学道之大病也，故云人之厌生死超生死者，皆是大息也。 譬如化人一若有厌生死心，超生死心，止名为妖，不名为道。 化人者，教北人也，历如为人师范，教化迷人学道，今人连厌离生。 死之心，超邃生死之心，止名为教人学妖怪不祥之事，岂名为教人学道哉！ 饮云譬如化人，若有厌生死心，超生死心，止名为妖，不名为道也。 此章明了道者无生死之可厌超也。
chunks.translated_text:
Gathering means nurturing. Benevolence pertains to yang and brightness, and may lighten the *hun*-soul. Righteousness pertains to yin and darkness, and may govern the *po*-soul. Benevolence corresponds to wood in the Five Phases, as does the *hun*-soul. Benevolence nurtures the self through stillness and benefits others through compassion. Compassion and goodness belong to yang; stillness brings clarity. Thus the *hun*-spirit becomes light and pure, limpid and deep. Hence it is said: "Benevolence pertains to yang and brightness, and may lighten the *hun*-soul." Righteousness corresponds to metal in the Five Phases, as does the *po*-soul. Profoundly comprehending true emptiness, it unites with the Dao in authenticity. Concealed in yin’s hidden depths, it causes the *shi-po* to rest in stillness and become clear and penetrating. Hence it is said: "Righteousness pertains to yin and darkness, and may govern the *po*-soul." To govern means to cause to rest. This chapter elucidates the wondrous functions of the Five Constants as the Dao.

---

**Chapter Twelve**
Master Guan Yin said: The dung beetle rolls a pellet. When the pellet is formed, it concentrates its spirit upon it, and a white grub comes to dwell within. Soon it sheds its husk and becomes a cicada. The dung beetle rolls dung into a pellet. Once the pellet is formed, it burrows into the earth, embracing the pellet with single-minded focus. The beetle’s spirit and qi enter the pellet, transforming into a white grub. Nurtured through autumn, winter, and spring, warmed by summer’s fire-like qi, it emerges from the soil and climbs grasses, trees, or walls. In an instant, its back splits open; it sheds its husk and becomes a cicada, flying among the trees, sipping wind and dew as it sings. Hence it is said: "The dung beetle rolls a pellet. When the pellet is formed, it concentrates its spirit upon it, and a white grub comes to dwell within. Soon it sheds its husk and becomes a cicada." If the beetle does not concentrate its spirit, how could the grub come to be? All transformations follow deluded thoughts, and form changes accordingly. Thus it is said: "If the beetle does not concentrate its spirit, how could the grub come to be?" *Xi* means "how." This chapter clarifies that the transformations of life and death all arise from deluded attachment.

---

**Chapter Thirteen**
Master Guan Yin said: A cook was preparing mantis shrimp. He left one leg upon the table, and though the shrimp had been cooked, the discarded leg still twitched. Life and death are but the gathering and dispersal of a single qi. When a cook prepares mantis shrimp, leaving one leg upon the table, the shrimp may be cooked, yet the discarded leg still moves. From this we know that life and death are but the gathering and dispersal of a single qi. When qi gathers, life arises; when qi disperses, death follows. That the discarded leg still moves shows the qi has not yet completely dissipated. Hence it is said: "A cook was preparing mantis shrimp. He left one leg upon the table, and though the shrimp had been cooked, the discarded leg still twitched. Life and death are but the gathering and dispersal of a single qi." That which is neither born nor dies—yet people falsely conceive of birth and death. *Heng* means delusion. The original face of true emptiness, the inherent nature, existed before the Five Ultimates. Before the Five Ultimates, there was not yet a single qi. From this we know that the nature of true emptiness does not belong to qi. Not belonging to qi, it has no gathering or dispersal. Without gathering or dispersal, there is no birth or death. Thus, those who fail to awaken to this nature see only the gathering of qi into form as birth and the dispersal of form as death—how could this not be a deluded conception? Hence it is said: "That which is neither born nor dies—yet people falsely conceive of birth and death." This chapter clarifies that the nature is fundamentally without birth or death; the deluded fear it out of ignorance.

---

**Chapter Fourteen**
Master Guan Yin said: There are those who die standing, those who die sitting, those who die suddenly, those who die from illness, and those who die from poison. Though their deaths differ, there is no distinction between them. In the world, some depart while standing, some while sitting, some in an instant, some from grave illness, and some from ingesting poison. Though the manner of death—standing, sitting, sudden, illness, or poison—varies, death itself is no different. There is no distinction between one death and another. Hence it is said: "There are those who die standing, those who die sitting, those who die suddenly, those who die from illness, and those who die from poison. Though their deaths differ, there is no distinction between them." The one who knows the Dao does not perceive birth, and thus does not perceive death. *Zhi* means awakening. The awakened one, having penetrated true emptiness, is free from birth and death in the heart. Turning inward, they see the four great elements as a temporary assemblage, like dust gathering and dispersing, like a thatched hut briefly lodging a traveler. They do not perceive birth or death as real. Hence it is said: "The one who knows the Dao does not perceive birth, and thus does not perceive death." This chapter clarifies that the Dao is without birth or death, and those who have realized the Dao perceive no birth or death.

---

**Chapter Fifteen**
Master Guan Yin said: Those who loathe life and death and seek to transcend them all suffer from a grave affliction. *Huan* means illness. The deluded, failing to realize that the Dao is without birth or death and that one can be free from them, cling to life and fear death. Before awakening, they conceive an aversion to life and death and seek to transcend them directly—this is the great affliction of the Dao-seeker. Hence it is said: "Those who loathe life and death and seek to transcend them all suffer from a grave affliction." For example, if a transformed being harbored such aversion and desire, it would be called a demon, not the Dao. A *hua-ren* is one who teaches and transforms others. For instance, if a teacher instructed the deluded to cultivate aversion to life and death and seek to transcend them, this would be teaching demonic and inauspicious practices—how could it be called teaching the Dao? Hence it is said: "For example, if a transformed being harbored such aversion and desire, it would be called a demon, not the Dao." This chapter clarifies that those who have realized the Dao perceive no life or death to loathe or transcend.

chunks.original_text: 右第十六章 关尹子曰：计生死者，或曰死已有，或曰死已无，或曰死已亦有亦无， 妄计生死之人，或曰假身如赁舍，舍壤人存，身死性存也，故云计生死者，或曰死已有也。 或有人曰，人生一世，草生一秋，人死如灯灭，已死则无有也，故云或曰死已无也。 或有人曰，人死无踪迹，却有附人而通传者，直疑亦有亦无也，故云或曰死已亦有亦无也。 或曰当喜者，或曰当惧者，或曰当任者，或曰当超者，愈变识情，驰骛不已。 或有人曰，生不灵而死灵，生不乐而死乐，惟神之有形，犹形之有疣，苟无其疣，何所不可如此不亦以死而为喜乎，故云曰当喜者也。 或有人曰，人死为鬼，冥冥长夜，无三光之所照，无家乡之所居，无相识之依托，无饮烁之所食，黑暗阴界，诚可惧也，故云或曰当惧者也。 或有人曰，人之生死，倏然而来，倏然而往，不喜不惧，任其自然，故云或曰当任者也。 或有人曰，人之生死，欲超不难，一志学道，直超生死，故云或曰当超者也。 向来妄计生死者，言死已有已无，亦有亦无，当喜惧任超之，八人所言#14，愈变妄识，迷情奔驰骛骤之不止也，故云愈变识情，驰骛不已也。 殊不知我之生死，如马之手，如牛之翼，本无有，复无无，譬如火水，虽犯火水，不能烧之，不能溺之。 向来妄计生死之人，殊不知本来元无生死，而妄计生死者，如妄计马有手而妄执，如牛有翼而妄飞，马牛本来无手翼，而妄计有手翼也，以譬喻则知本来元无有生死，复无无有也，故云殊不知我之生死，如马之手，如牛之翼，本无有，复无无也。 本来真空妙有，与太虚同体，以空合空，如以火投火，不问其明，火不烧火也，以水投水，不问其清，水不溺水也，故云譬如火水，虽犯火水，不能烧之，不能溺之也。 此章明情识不萌，元无生死也。 右第十七章 文始真经注卷之四竟

Chapter Sixteen

Master Guan Yin said: Those who speculate on life and death hold various views. Some say that after death, one continues to exist; some say that after death, one ceases to exist; some say that after death, one both exists and does not exist. Those who recklessly speculate on life and death may claim that the body is like a rented dwelling—when the dwelling crumbles, the person remains; when the body dies, the nature endures. Thus it is said: some say that after death, one continues to exist.

Others may say: a person lives for a lifetime, as grass lives for a season; when a person dies, it is like a lamp extinguished—once dead, nothing remains. Thus it is said: some say that after death, one ceases to exist.

Still others may say: when a person dies, no trace is left, yet some spirits attach to others and communicate, leaving one to doubt whether death is both existence and non-existence. Thus it is said: some say that after death, one both exists and does not exist.

Some say one should rejoice in death; some say one should fear it; some say one should accept it; some say one should transcend it. Such shifting perceptions and restless emotions race on without end.

Some may say: in life, one is not numinous, but in death, one becomes so; in life, one finds no joy, but in death, one does. The spirit having form is like form having a wart—if the wart were absent, what could not be achieved? Thus is death not cause for rejoicing? Hence it is said: some say one should rejoice in death.

Others may say: when a person dies, they become a ghost, dwelling in endless darkness where the three luminaries do not shine, where no homeland offers shelter, where no familiar faces provide solace, where no food or drink sustains them. The dark, shadowy netherworld is truly fearful. Hence it is said: some say one should fear death.

Still others may say: life and death come and go in an instant—neither joy nor fear is fitting; one should simply let them follow their natural course. Hence it is said: some say one should accept death.

And some may say: transcending life and death is not difficult—with single-minded devotion to the Dao, one may directly transcend them. Hence it is said: some say one should transcend death.

The preceding reckless speculations on life and death—whether death entails existence, non-existence, or both, whether one should rejoice, fear, accept, or transcend it—these eight views only multiply deluded perceptions, causing the emotions to gallop ceaselessly. Hence it is said: such shifting perceptions and restless emotions race on without end.

Yet they do not realize that my life and death are like a horse’s hand or an ox’s wing—fundamentally non-existent, and thus neither existent nor non-existent. It is like fire and water: though one may encounter fire and water, they cannot burn or drown one.

Those who recklessly speculate on life and death do not realize that life and death are originally non-existent. Their speculations are like imagining a horse has hands or an ox has wings and clinging to such delusions. Horses and oxen naturally have no hands or wings, yet they imagine them to exist. This analogy reveals that life and death are fundamentally neither existent nor non-existent. Hence it is said: they do not realize that my life and death are like a horse’s hand or an ox’s wing—fundamentally non-existent, and thus neither existent nor non-existent.

The original true emptiness and wondrous existence are one with the great void. Emptiness merging with emptiness is like fire meeting fire—its brightness is not questioned, for fire does not burn fire. Water meeting water—its clarity is not questioned, for water does not drown water. Hence it is said: it is like fire and water—though one may encounter fire and water, they cannot burn or drown one.

This chapter clarifies that when perceptions and consciousness do not arise, life and death are fundamentally non-existent.

Chapter Seventeen concludes *Commentary on the Wenshi Zhenjing*, Volume Four.

**Chapter Eighteen**

1. "Five Duties" (*wudang*) is an error for "Five Constants" (*wuchang*).
2. "Abandoning resolve" (*qu yi*) is incorrect; both the *Guan Yinzi* and the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao* read "the gate sheds its husk" (*men qu qiao*).
3. The passage beginning "Only water as a thing..." does not appear in either the *Guan Yinzi* or the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao*.
4. This line should read: "Within humans, the Five Spirits become spirit" (*zai ren wu shen ze wei shen ye*); the characters "then the human Five Spirits" (*ze ren wu shen*) are superfluous.
5. "King Spirit" (*wang shen*) is an error for "Five Spirits" (*wu shen*).
6. This line appears in both the *Guan Yinzi* and the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao* as: "All are gathered in a single breath" (*jie she zhi yi xi*).
7. This line appears in both the *Guan Yinzi* and the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao* as: "Know that things are non-things" (*zhi wu wu wu*).
8. "Return to that" (*fan bi*) is likely an error for "returned to by" (*fan bei*).
9–10. These two lines appear in both the *Guan Yinzi* and the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao* as: "Only the numerology of the Five Phases" (*wei wu xing zhi shu*).
11. Based on the preceding classical text, this line should read: "All share the same consciousness of arising" (*jie tong shi sheng ye*).
12. This line appears in the *Guan Yinzi* as: "The hun-soul is Wood" (*hun zhe mu ye*).
13. "As for forgetting essence" (*ruo fu wang jing*) appears in both the *Guan Yinzi* and the *Wenshi Zhenjing of the Supreme Wondrous Dao* as: "As for forgetting spirit and essence" (*ruo fu wang jing shen*).
14. "What the eight people say" (*ba ren suo yan*) is likely an error for "what all people say" (*ren ren suo yan*).

Direct Explication by Shenfeng Xiaoyaozi Niu Daochun

chunks.original_text: 五鉴篇 鉴者，心也，凡二十章。 关尹子曰：心蔽吉凶者，灵鬼摄之，心蔽男女者，淫鬼摄之，心蔽幽忧者，沉鬼摄之，心蔽逐放者，狂鬼摄之，心蔽盟诅者，奇鬼摄之，心蔽药饵者，物鬼摄之。 蔽者，执蔽也，蒙昧也，人心专一执蔽吉凶祸福、五行阴阳者，则有灵通之鬼统摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽吉凶者，灵鬼摄之也； 人心专一执蔽婴妮夫妇、御女探战之衍，则有淫欲之鬼统摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽男女者，淫鬼摄之也； 人心专一执蔽幽暗忧愁，则沉溺之鬼摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽幽忧者，况鬼摄之也； 人心专一执蔽逐走放飞畋猎者，则有狂荡之鬼统摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽逐放者，狂鬼摄之也； 人心专一执蔽盟誓呢诅者，则奇异之鬼统摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽盟诅者，奇鬼摄之也； 人心专一执蔽修合服食药饵者，则有药物之鬼统摄而蒙昧也，故云心蔽药饵者，物鬼摄之也。 如是之鬼，或以阴为身，或以幽为身，或以风为身，或以气为身，或以土偶为身，或以彩画为身，或以老畜为身，或以败器为身。 如上所说，灵鬼、淫鬼、沉鬼、狂鬼、奇鬼、物鬼，六等之鬼，统摄蒙昧六等执蔽之人也，故云如是之鬼也。 鬼无形相，铃附托物以为身，或以附托阴影为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以阴为身也； 鬼或有附托幽暗以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以幽为身也； 鬼或有附托旋风以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以风为身也； 鬼或有附托阴气以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以气为身也； 鬼或有附托土偶塑人以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以土偶为身也； 鬼或有附托彩画人物之像以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以彩画为身也； 鬼或有附托老畜走兽以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以老畜为身也； 鬼或有附托败坏器物以为身，而见形昧人者，故云或以败器为身也。 彼以其精，此以其精，两精相搏，而神应之。 彼者，附托阴、幽、风、气、土偶、彩画、老畜、败器八者之鬼也，此者，心蔽吉凶、男女、幽忧、逐放、盟诅、药饵六者之人也，为此人专一执蔽已上六者之事，精执不移，彼附托鬼之精，与人精两相激搏，而鬼有灵通神异之应也。 故云彼以其精，此以其精，两精相搏，而神应之也。 为鬼所摄者，或解奇事，或解异事，或解瑞事，其人傲然，不曰鬼于躬，惟曰道于躬， 心执蔽之人，为灵淫况狂奇物六鬼统摄蒙昧者，或解珍奇之事，或解异怪之事，或解祥瑞之事，预言铃应，众人敬之以为圣，其解奇异瑞事之人，傲然不言有鬼附於身，唯言至道於身有此灵通也。 故云为鬼所摄者，或解奇事，或解异事，或解瑞事，其人傲然，不曰鬼于躬，惟曰道于躬也。 久之，或死木，或死金，或死绳，或死井。 为鬼所摄之人，预解奇异瑞事，傲然以为得道，久之，或自触树木而死，或以刀刃自刎而死，或以绳自缢而死，或自投井而死也。 故云久之，或死木，或死金，或死绳，或死井也。 惟圣人能神神，而不神於神，役万神而执其机，可以会之，可以散之，可以御之，曰应万物，其心寂然。 惟有了道圣人，洞彻真空妙有，了悟不神之神，阴阳莫测，神鬼难窥，化身周遍尘沙界，妙用神通无量，韬晦不显也，故云惟圣人能神神，而不神於神也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Five: The Five Mirrors**

A mirror is the heart; this chapter contains twenty sections.

Master Guan Yin said: When the heart is obscured by fortune and misfortune, numinous ghosts seize it. When the heart is obscured by male and female, lewd ghosts seize it. When the heart is obscured by hidden sorrow, drowning ghosts seize it. When the heart is obscured by reckless pursuit, mad ghosts seize it. When the heart is obscured by oaths and curses, strange ghosts seize it. When the heart is obscured by medicines and elixirs, material ghosts seize it.

Obscuration means fixation and delusion. When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on fortune and misfortune, the Five Phases, and yin and yang, then ghosts of numinous penetration seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by fortune and misfortune, numinous ghosts seize it.” When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on the entanglements of husband and wife, the arts of bedchamber union, and sexual combat, then lewd ghosts seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by male and female, lewd ghosts seize it.” When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on dark sorrow and melancholy, drowning ghosts seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by hidden sorrow, drowning ghosts seize it.” When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on reckless hunting and wandering, mad ghosts seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by reckless pursuit, mad ghosts seize it.” When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on oaths, vows, and curses, strange ghosts seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by oaths and curses, strange ghosts seize it.” When a person’s heart is singularly fixated on compounding and consuming medicines and elixirs, material ghosts seize and delude it—hence it is said, “When the heart is obscured by medicines and elixirs, material ghosts seize it.”

Such ghosts may take yin as their bodies, or darkness as their bodies, or wind as their bodies, or qi as their bodies, or clay effigies as their bodies, or painted images as their bodies, or old beasts as their bodies, or broken vessels as their bodies.

As stated above, the six kinds of ghosts—numinous, lewd, drowning, mad, strange, and material—seize and delude the six kinds of people fixated on obscurations. Thus it is said, “Such are these ghosts.”

Ghosts have no form or appearance; they must attach to things to take shape. Some attach to shadows to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take yin as their bodies.” Some attach to darkness to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take darkness as their bodies.” Some attach to whirlwinds to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take wind as their bodies.” Some attach to yin qi to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take qi as their bodies.” Some attach to clay effigies to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take clay effigies as their bodies.” Some attach to painted figures to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take painted images as their bodies.” Some attach to old beasts to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take old beasts as their bodies.” Some attach to broken vessels to form bodies and appear to delude people—hence it is said, “Some take broken vessels as their bodies.”

Theirs is their essence; ours is our essence. When the two essences clash, the spirit responds.

“Theirs” refers to the ghosts that attach to the eight things—yin, darkness, wind, qi, clay effigies, painted images, old beasts, and broken vessels. “Ours” refers to the six kinds of people whose hearts are obscured by fortune and misfortune, male and female, hidden sorrow, reckless pursuit, oaths and curses, and medicines and elixirs. When such people are singularly fixated on these six matters, their essence becomes unyielding. The essence of the attaching ghosts and the essence of the person clash, and the ghosts manifest numinous and wondrous responses. Thus it is said, “Theirs is their essence; ours is our essence. When the two essences clash, the spirit responds.”

Those seized by ghosts may explain strange matters, extraordinary matters, or auspicious matters. Such people grow arrogant, claiming not that ghosts possess them but that the Dao possesses them.

People whose hearts are fixated and deluded by the six ghosts—numinous, lewd, drowning, mad, strange, and material—may explain rare and wondrous matters, strange and uncanny matters, or auspicious and prophetic matters. Their predictions invariably come true, and the multitude reveres them as sages. Yet those who explain such strange and auspicious matters grow arrogant, refusing to admit that ghosts possess them, insisting instead that the supreme Dao has granted them such numinous penetration. Thus it is said, “Those seized by ghosts may explain strange matters, extraordinary matters, or auspicious matters. Such people grow arrogant, claiming not that ghosts possess them but that the Dao possesses them.”

In time, they may die by wood, die by metal, die by rope, or die by well.

Those seized by ghosts, who arrogantly believe themselves to have attained the Dao after explaining strange and auspicious matters, may in time die by crashing into trees, by cutting their throats with blades, by hanging themselves with ropes, or by throwing themselves into wells. Thus it is said, “In time, they may die by wood, die by metal, die by rope, or die by well.”

Only the sage can spiritually engage with spirits without being ensnared by them, commanding the myriad spirits while grasping their mechanism. They can gather them, disperse them, or master them, responding to the ten thousand things while their heart remains serene.

Only the sage who has attained the Dao, who thoroughly comprehends the wondrous interplay of emptiness and existence, who awakens to the spirit that is not spirit, whose yin and yang are unfathomable, whose transformations pervade the dust-like worlds, whose wondrous functions are boundless, and whose subtlety remains concealed—only such a sage can spiritually engage with spirits without being ensnared by them. Thus it is said, “Only the sage can spiritually engage with spirits without being ensnared by them.”

chunks.original_text: 了道圣人能呼召风雨，役使万神而执机也，执者，把握也。 了道圣人不唯能呼召风雨，而役使万神，更能使可以会而聚之，可以散而分之，可以御而止之也，故云可以会之，可以散之，可以御之也。 了道圣人之心，如月印众水，如风呜万籁，如悬镜镒形，如空谷传声，应变而常寂常明，常清常静也，故云曰应万物，其心寂然也。 此章明心有执蔽皆邪心，无蔽皆道也。 右第一章 关尹子曰：无一心，五识并驰，心不可一，无虚心，五行皆具，心不可虚，无静心，万化密移，心不可静。 无者，禁止之辞也，谓本来妙心，元自不二，垂诫学人无得专心守一，若萌专心守一之念，则守一之念，与视听食息思之五识相并奔驰，不得一也，以此明了，则知心不可守一也，故云无一心，五识并驰，心不可一也。 本来妙心元无一物，等同太虚，垂械学人无得专心虚廓，若萌专心虚廓之念，与喜火、怒木、思土、忧金、恐水之五行，皆同具足不得虚也。 以此明了，则知心不萌虚廓之念也，故云无虚心，五行皆具，心不可虚也，本来妙心元自清静，垂诫学人无得专心守静，若蒙专心守静之念，与万化密迁移而不得静也，以此明了，则知心不可守静也，故云无静心，万化密移，心不可静也。 借能一则二偶之，借能虚则实满之，借能静则动摇之。 本来妙心元自不二，於不二妙心，萌守一之念，则守一之念，与不二妙心为二偶对也，故云借能一则二偶之也，此释心不可一也。 本来妙心元无一物，等同太虚，於此无物妙心，萌专虚廓之念，则专虚廓之念，填实满塞无物之妙心也，故云借能虚则实满之也，此释心不可虚也。 本来妙心元自清静，犹如虚空无动无摇，於本静妙心，萌守静之念，守静之念既生，则是动摇妙心也，故云借能静则动摇之也，此释心不可静也。 惟圣人能敛万有於一息，无有一物可役吾之明彻，散一息於万有，无有一物可问吾之云为。 惟了道圣人之心，犹如太虚，无所不容，化身亿万，一息之问，返本还源，如一切水月，一真月统摄其水月波流，无有一水可没溺真月之明彻也，故云惟圣人能敛万有於一息，无有一物可役吾之明彻也。 了道圣人，一息之问，散布化身周遍尘沙界，如一真月普见一切水也，一切水波流不停，无有一切水可问断真月之光明云为照耀也，故云散一息於万有，无有一物可问吾之云为也。 此章明本来妙心元自不二，虚静应变纵夺无妨也。 右第二章 关尹子曰：火千年，俄可灭，识千年，俄可去。 火本无我，因膏因薪而见形，虽千年之久，若俄顷膏薪俱尽，则火亦随之而灭也，故云火千年俄可灭也，此起喻也。 迷人业识忙忙，无本可据，轮回亿劫，不能出离者，皆因此识也。 识亦无我，依境而见，虽千万年之久，若蒙师点化，直下顿悟，本来妙心元自清静，等同太虚，则俄顷之问，境忘识去矣，如薪尽火灭也，故云识千年俄可去也。 此喻也。 此章明识是生死根，境忘识去，出轮回之要者也。 右第三章 关尹子曰：流者舟也，所以流之者，是水非舟，运者车也，所以运之者，是牛非车，思者心也，所以思之者，是意非合o 人但见舟之流行，殊不知所以使舟流行者，是水流行，非舟自能流行也，故云流者舟也，所以流之者，是水非舟也。
chunks.translated_text:
The enlightened sage who has attained the Dao can summon wind and rain, command the myriad spirits, and grasp their mechanism—*grasp* meaning to hold and master. Not only can such a sage summon wind and rain and command the myriad spirits, but they can also gather them when they may be assembled, disperse them when they may be divided, and restrain them when they may be controlled. Thus it is said, “They can gather them, disperse them, or master them.”

The heart of the enlightened sage is like the moon reflected in all waters, like the wind resounding through the myriad sounds, like a mirror suspended to reflect all forms, like an empty valley transmitting all echoes—responding to change while ever still and luminous, ever pure and tranquil. Thus it is said, “They respond to the ten thousand things while their heart remains serene.”

This chapter clarifies that any heart bound by attachments is a deluded heart, while the unbound heart is the Dao.

**Chapter One**
Master Guan Yin said: Do not fixate on oneness, for the five senses will race in parallel—if the heart cannot be one, it is because oneness cannot be fixed. Do not seek emptiness, for the five phases will all arise—if the heart cannot be empty, it is because emptiness cannot be forced. Do not cling to stillness, for the ten thousand transformations will shift imperceptibly—if the heart cannot be still, it is because stillness cannot be grasped.

*Do not* is a prohibitive term, for the wondrous heart is originally non-dual. It warns the learner not to single-mindedly pursue oneness. If the thought of fixating on oneness arises, that very thought will race alongside the five senses—sight, hearing, taste, breath, and thought—preventing true unity. Through this understanding, one knows the heart cannot be forced into oneness. Thus it is said, “Do not fixate on oneness, for the five senses will race in parallel—the heart cannot be one.”

The wondrous heart is originally empty of all things, equal to the great void. It warns the learner not to single-mindedly pursue emptiness. If the thought of forcing emptiness arises, it will align with the five phases—joy as fire, anger as wood, thought as earth, sorrow as metal, and fear as water—all arising together, preventing true emptiness. Through this understanding, one knows the heart cannot be forced into emptiness. Thus it is said, “Do not seek emptiness, for the five phases will all arise—the heart cannot be empty.”

The wondrous heart is originally pure and still, like empty space, without movement or disturbance. It warns the learner not to single-mindedly cling to stillness. If the thought of fixating on stillness arises, it will be swept away by the imperceptible shifts of the ten thousand transformations, preventing true stillness. Through this understanding, one knows the heart cannot be forced into stillness. Thus it is said, “Do not cling to stillness, for the ten thousand transformations will shift imperceptibly—the heart cannot be still.”

To borrow oneness is to create duality; to borrow emptiness is to invite fullness; to borrow stillness is to invite movement. The wondrous heart is originally non-dual. If one fixates on oneness, that fixation becomes a duality opposing the non-dual heart. Thus it is said, “To borrow oneness is to create duality,” explaining why the heart cannot be one.

The wondrous heart is originally empty of all things, equal to the great void. If one fixates on emptiness, that fixation fills and obstructs the empty heart. Thus it is said, “To borrow emptiness is to invite fullness,” explaining why the heart cannot be empty.

The wondrous heart is originally still, like empty space, without movement or disturbance. If one fixates on stillness, that fixation itself becomes movement, disturbing the heart. Thus it is said, “To borrow stillness is to invite movement,” explaining why the heart cannot be still.

Only the sage can gather the ten thousand existences into a single breath, so that not a single thing can obscure their clarity. They can disperse a single breath into the ten thousand existences, so that not a single thing can inquire into their actions.

The heart of the enlightened sage is like the great void, all-embracing. Their transformed bodies number in the billions, yet in a single breath, they return to the source—like all water-moons under the one true moon, which governs the flowing waves of water-moons without any water ever drowning the true moon’s clarity. Thus it is said, “Only the sage can gather the ten thousand existences into a single breath, so that not a single thing can obscure their clarity.”

The enlightened sage, in a single breath, scatters their transformed bodies throughout the dust-like worlds—like the one true moon appearing in all waters. The ceaseless flow of water-waves cannot interrupt the true moon’s luminous actions and radiance. Thus it is said, “They can disperse a single breath into the ten thousand existences, so that not a single thing can inquire into their actions.”

This chapter clarifies that the wondrous heart is originally non-dual, empty, and still—responding to change without hindrance.

**Chapter Two**
Master Guan Yin said: A fire may burn for a thousand years, yet it can be extinguished in an instant. Consciousness may persist for a thousand years, yet it can be dissolved in an instant.

Fire has no self; it takes form through oil and fuel. Though it may burn for a thousand years, if the oil and fuel are suddenly exhausted, the fire will be extinguished. Thus it is said, “A fire may burn for a thousand years, yet it can be extinguished in an instant.” This begins the analogy.

The deluded mind races with karmic consciousness, without any true foundation. Trapped in the cycle of rebirth for countless eons, it cannot escape—all due to this consciousness.

Consciousness also has no self; it arises dependent on conditions. Though it may persist for ten thousand years, if one is suddenly awakened by a teacher’s guidance and directly realizes the wondrous heart—originally pure and still, equal to the great void—then in an instant, conditions vanish and consciousness dissolves, like a fire extinguished when the fuel is gone. Thus it is said, “Consciousness may persist for a thousand years, yet it can be dissolved in an instant.” This completes the analogy.

This chapter clarifies that consciousness is the root of birth and death, and the key to escaping the cycle lies in forgetting conditions and dissolving consciousness.

**Chapter Three**
Master Guan Yin said: What flows is the boat, but what causes it to flow is the water, not the boat. What moves is the cart, but what causes it to move is the ox, not the cart. What thinks is the heart, but what causes it to think is intention, not the heart.

People see only the boat’s movement, unaware that what truly moves it is the flowing water—the boat cannot move itself. Thus it is said, “What flows is the boat, but what causes it to flow is the water, not the boat.”

Thus it is said, “Only the sage can spiritually engage with spirits without being ensnared by them.”

chunks.original_text: 人但见车之运行，殊不知所以使车运行者，是牛拽之运行，非车能自运行也，故云运者车也，所以运之者，是牛非车也。 此舟车二者借喻也。 人但知心之思虑，殊不知所以能思虑者，是意识能思虑，非本来妙心有思虑也，故云思者心也，所以思之者，是意非心也。 此合喻也。 不知所以然而然，惟不知所以然而然，故其来无从，其往无在。 本来妙心，真空为体，妙有为用，体用如如，应变无穷，神鬼难窥，阴阳莫测，不知所以然而然也。 不知所以然而然，本来妙心，元在五太之前，象帝之先，洞然明了，其来不知从何而生来，冥然隐密其往，不知所在而居止，故云不知所以然而然。 惟不知所以然而然，故其来无从，其往无在也。 其来无从，其往无在，故能与天地本原，不古不今。 迭上二句，谓本来妙心，不知从何而生来，冥然隐密往，然不知所在，如此，天地与吾同本原，妙心而生本原，妙心不属时节，故不古不今也，故云其来无从，其往无在，故能与天地本原，不古不今也。 此章明本原妙心禀自五太之前，非思虑之所知也。 右第四章 关尹子曰：知心无物，则知物无物，知物无物，则知道无物，知道无物，故不尊卓绝之行，不惊微妙之言。 本来妙心，以道为体，以物为用，了悟道心，元无一物，等同虚空，体用如如，应变常寂，故云知心无物，则知物无物，知物无物，则知道无物也。 知者，悟也，物无物者，应变常寂也。 洞悟道心体用无物，故不尊尚卓高绝代之行，为行虽卓绝，不离於迹，道本无迹，故不尊尚也。 不惊异精微玄妙之言，为言虽微妙，不离於名，道本无名，故不惊异也。 故云知道无物，故不尊卓绝之行，不惊微妙之言也。 此章明道心应变常寂，非言行之可及也。 右第五章 关尹子曰：物我交心生，两木摩火生， 心本无心，因物而见，物我相交而心生显见，如两木相钻摩而生火也，故云物我交心生，两木摩火生也。 不可谓之在我，不可谓之在彼，不可谓之非我，不可谓之非彼，执而彼我之，则愚。 我本无我，因物来干，心忽显见，非我自生心也，故云不可谓之在我也。 物来相感，心虽显见，心如虚空，与彼物无碍，故云不可谓之在彼也。 若无我者，物虽来感，则心不生，心既有生，不可谓之非我也，故云不可谓之非我也。 我未无我#1彼物若不来感，则心亦不生，心本不生，因感而生，不可谓之非彼物也，故云不可谓之非彼也。 迷人不悟无我无心，与物无碍，而妄立我心，与物作对，执有彼我，触物有碍，非愚而何，故云执而彼我之则愚也。 而者，汝也，执汝彼我而不忘，乃愚迷之人也。 此章明心本无彼我，与物无碍，迷人妄立彼我，与物作对也。 右第六章 关尹子曰：无恃尔所谓利害是非，尔所谓利害是非者，果得利害是非之乎， 无者，禁止之辞也，恃者，倚赖也，言无得恃赖汝之所言利害是非也，故云无恃尔所谓利害是非也。 汝所言利害是非者，皆妄情无计，岂可利定为利，害定为害，是定为是，非定为非，利害是非随妄情变化，岂可一定之邪？ 既不可一定，随时妄情所计之耳，果何得利害是非者哉！ 故云尔所谓利害是非者，果得利害是非之乎。 圣人方且不识不知，而况於尔。

People see only the cart’s movement, unaware that what truly moves it is the ox’s pulling— the cart cannot move itself. Thus it is said, “What moves is the cart, but what causes it to move is the ox, not the cart.” These two analogies of boat and cart are borrowed comparisons.

People know only the heart’s thoughts, unaware that what enables thought is the intention and consciousness— the inherently wondrous heart does not think of itself. Thus it is said, “What thinks is the heart, but what causes it to think is intention, not the heart.” This is the combined analogy.

Not knowing the cause yet seeing the effect, only by not knowing the cause can one see the effect. Thus its coming has no source, its going no abode. The inherently wondrous heart takes true emptiness as its essence and wondrous existence as its function. Essence and function are thus, responding to change without end. Spirits and ghosts cannot fathom it; yin and yang cannot measure it— not knowing the cause yet seeing the effect.

Not knowing the cause yet seeing the effect, the inherently wondrous heart originally existed before the Five Ultimates, prior to the appearance of the Lord of Creation. Radiantly clear and luminous, its coming is unknown— whence it arises. Profoundly hidden and obscure, its going is unknown— where it resides. Thus it is said, “Not knowing the cause yet seeing the effect.” Only by not knowing the cause can one see the effect, so its coming has no source, its going no abode.

Its coming has no source, its going no abode, thus it can unite with the primordial origin of heaven and earth, neither ancient nor modern. The preceding two lines mean that the inherently wondrous heart, not knowing whence it arises, profoundly hidden in its going, yet unknown in its abode— thus heaven and earth share the same origin with me. The wondrous heart gives rise to the primordial origin, yet the wondrous heart does not belong to time, hence neither ancient nor modern. Thus it is said, its coming has no source, its going no abode, so it can unite with the primordial origin of heaven and earth, neither ancient nor modern.

This chapter clarifies that the inherently wondrous heart is endowed from before the Five Ultimates, beyond the reach of discursive thought.

**Chapter Five**
Master Guan Yin said: Know that the heart is without thing, then know that things are without thing. Know that things are without thing, then know that the Dao is without thing. Know that the Dao is without thing, thus one does not esteem lofty and peerless conduct nor marvel at subtle and wondrous words.

The inherently wondrous heart takes the Dao as its essence and things as its function. Awakening to the heart of the Dao, it is fundamentally without a single thing, equal to empty space. Essence and function are thus, responding to change yet ever tranquil. Thus it is said, “Know that the heart is without thing, then know that things are without thing. Know that things are without thing, then know that the Dao is without thing.”

“Know” means awakening. “Things without thing” means responding to change yet ever tranquil. Penetratingly awakening to the heart of the Dao, its essence and function without thing, thus one does not esteem lofty and peerless conduct. Though conduct may be lofty and peerless, it does not depart from traces, yet the Dao is originally without trace, hence one does not esteem it. Nor does one marvel at subtle and wondrous words. Though words may be profound and wondrous, they do not depart from names, yet the Dao is originally without name, hence one does not marvel at them. Thus it is said, “Know that the Dao is without thing, thus one does not esteem lofty and peerless conduct nor marvel at subtle and wondrous words.”

This chapter clarifies that the heart of the Dao responds to change yet remains ever tranquil, beyond the reach of words and conduct.

**Chapter Six**
Master Guan Yin said: When self and things interact, the heart arises— just as fire is born from two sticks rubbing. The heart is originally without heart; it appears through things. When self and things interact, the heart becomes manifest, like fire born from two sticks rubbing together. Thus it is said, “When self and things interact, the heart arises; two sticks rubbing produce fire.”

It cannot be said to be within me, nor within that, nor as not-me, nor as not-that. To cling to self and other is foolish.

The self is originally without self; when things come to interact, the heart suddenly appears— it is not that the heart arises from the self. Thus it cannot be said to be within me. When things come to interact, though the heart appears, the heart is like empty space, unimpeded by those things. Thus it cannot be said to be within that. If there were no self, though things came to interact, the heart would not arise. Since the heart has arisen, it cannot be said to be not-me. Thus it cannot be said to be not-me. If that thing did not come to interact, the heart would also not arise. The heart does not originally arise; it arises through interaction. Thus it cannot be said to be not-that. Thus it cannot be said to be not-that.

Deluded people, not awakening to the absence of self and heart, unimpeded by things, falsely establish a self and set it against things. Clinging to self and other, they encounter obstacles with things— what is this if not foolishness? Thus it is said, “To cling to self and other is foolish.” “And” refers to you; clinging to self and other without forgetting is the mark of a deluded person.

This chapter clarifies that the heart is originally without self and other, unimpeded by things. Deluded people falsely establish self and other, setting them against things.

**Chapter Seven**
Master Guan Yin said: Do not rely on what you call benefit and harm, right and wrong. As for what you call benefit and harm, right and wrong— do they truly attain benefit and harm, right and wrong?

“Do not” is a prohibitive term; “rely” means to depend upon. It means one should not depend upon what you call benefit and harm, right and wrong. Thus it is said, “Do not rely on what you call benefit and harm, right and wrong.” What you call benefit and harm, right and wrong are all deluded feelings without measure. How can benefit be definitively benefit, harm definitively harm, right definitively right, wrong definitively wrong? Benefit and harm, right and wrong change with deluded feelings— how can they be fixed? Since they cannot be fixed, they are merely what deluded feelings calculate at the time— how can they truly attain benefit and harm, right and wrong? Thus it is said, “As for what you call benefit and harm, right and wrong— do they truly attain benefit and harm, right and wrong?”

The sage goes so far as to be without knowledge or awareness— how much more so for you?

People see only the boat’s movement, unaware that what truly moves it is the flowing water—the boat cannot move itself. Thus it is said, “What flows is the boat, but what causes it to flow is the water, not the boat.”
