chunks.original_text: 圣人不能使手步足握，是以圣人不违我所长，圣人不能使鱼飞禽驰，是以圣人不违人所长。 以掘为手所长，以步为足所长，虽圣人岂能使手步足握，易手足之用哉，以此圣人不违拒我之六用所长也，故云圣人不能使手步足握，是以圣人不违我所长也。 长者以能为为长，以不能为为短也，鱼以水中能游为长也，禽以空中能飞腾为长也，驰者，马走速也，虽圣人，岂能易鱼禽游驰飞腾哉，以此圣人不违拒众人所长之用也，故云圣人不能使鱼飞禽驰，是以圣人不违人所长也。 夫如是者，可动可止，可晦可明，惟不可拘，所以为道。 如是者，已上所说圣人不违时、不违俗、不违我所长、不违人所长之四者也。 如此不违四者，可动时，亦不违时之动，可止时，亦不违时之止，可晦时，亦不违时之晦，可明时，亦不· 迟时之明。 惟能不违拒造物之变化，不拘泥於死法，所以应变无穷而为妙道也。 故云夫如是者，可动可止，可晦可明，惟不可拘，所以为道也。 此章明治不能随时达变之病也。 右第十六章 关尹子曰：少言者，不为人所忌； 少行者，不为人所短； 少智者，不为人所劳； 少能者，不为人所役。 学道之人，慎言俭语则寡过，不为众人之所忌惮也，故云少言者，不为人所忌也。 於利名场上，慎多贵进行履，则不为众人所嫉坏短遏也，故云少行者，不为人所短也。 智慧收藏，俭於使用，则不为众人之所劳苦也，故云少智者，不为人所劳也。 大巧若拙，检施其能，则不为众人所役使也，故云少能者，不为人所役也。 此章明治不能忘言行智能之病也。 右第十七章 关尹子曰：操之以诚，行之以简，待之以恕，应之以默，吾道不穷。 操者，持也，诚者，真实也，简者，不繁也，行者，无住也，待者，应也，恕者，宽裕包容也。 了悟真空实有，保任护持，无住种种之边，如此简当不繁也，故云操之以诚，行之以简也。 与众同处，或御群下，但应之以宽裕包容，不见人之过失，曲全己德也，故云待之以恕也。 或有人来叩问，但动容密示，不假言教，利根顿悟，与吾所悟之道俱无穷极也，故云应之以默，吾道不穷也。 此章明治不达诚简恕默之病也。 右第十八章 关尹子曰：谋之於事，断之於理，作之於人，成之於天，事师於今，理师於古，事同於人，道独於己。 图谋人事，以理裁断而合其宜也，故云谋之於事，断之於理也。 所作之事，力与不力在人为，而成与不成在天命也，故云作之於人，成之於天也。 事以今人为师，理以古人为师也，故云事师於今，理师於古也。 事者用也，用虽与众人同，而了悟妙道，应变常寂，无染清静，不与众人同也，故云事同於人，道独於己也。 此章明治不能事理圆通之病者也。 右第十九章 关尹子曰：金玉难捐，土石易舍，学道之士，遇微言妙行，慎勿执之，是可为而不可执，若执之者，腹心之疾，无药可疗。 金玉者，喻圣人之言行也，土石者，喻几人之言行也，金玉虽贵，入眼为尘，大道无名迹，故言行不可及也，学人於圣人之言行难忘，如世人难拾金玉也，故云金玉难捐也。 学人於几人之言行容易忘之，如世人易拾土石也，故云土石易拾也。 学道之士，若遇圣人微言妙行，慎勿执着不忘也，故云学道之士，遇微言妙行，慎勿执之也。
chunks.translated_text:
The sage cannot make hands walk or feet grasp, thus the sage does not defy the strengths of the self. The sage cannot make fish fly or birds gallop, thus the sage does not defy the strengths of others. Digging is the strength of the hand, walking the strength of the foot—how could even a sage make hands walk or feet grasp, exchanging their functions? Thus the sage does not defy the six faculties’ inherent strengths. Hence it is said: The sage cannot make hands walk or feet grasp, thus the sage does not defy the strengths of the self. Strength lies in what one can do, weakness in what one cannot. Fish excel at swimming in water, birds at soaring in the sky, and galloping is the swiftness of horses—how could even a sage alter the swimming of fish, the flight of birds, or the gallop of horses? Thus the sage does not defy the strengths of others. Hence it is said: The sage cannot make fish fly or birds gallop, thus the sage does not defy the strengths of others.

Such is the Way: it may move or halt, conceal or reveal, yet remains unbound. This refers to the four principles mentioned above—where the sage does not defy the times, does not defy customs, does not defy the self’s strengths, and does not defy others’ strengths. Adhering to these four, one may act when the time is right without defying the time’s movement, rest when the time is right without defying the time’s stillness, conceal when the time is right without defying the time’s obscurity, and reveal when the time is right without defying the time’s clarity. Only by not resisting the transformations of creation and not clinging to rigid methods can one respond endlessly to change and embody the subtle Dao. Hence it is said: Such is the Way—it may move or halt, conceal or reveal, yet remains unbound.

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to adapt to the times.

---

**Chapter Sixteen**
Master Guan Yin said: Those who speak little are not resented by others; those who act little are not criticized by others; those who use little wisdom are not wearied by others; those who display little ability are not employed by others.

Those who study the Dao guard their words and moderate their speech to avoid faults, thus escaping the resentment of the multitude. Hence it is said: Those who speak little are not resented by others. In the arena of profit and fame, those who restrain their conduct and limit their actions avoid the envy and obstruction of others. Hence it is said: Those who act little are not criticized by others. Those who conceal their wisdom and use it sparingly avoid the toil imposed by others. Hence it is said: Those who use little wisdom are not wearied by others. Those who appear clumsy yet temper their skills avoid being enslaved by others. Hence it is said: Those who display little ability are not employed by others.

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to forget words, actions, wisdom, and ability.

---

**Chapter Seventeen**
Master Guan Yin said: Hold fast to sincerity, act with simplicity, respond with forbearance, and answer in silence—thus my Dao knows no end.

To "hold fast" is to maintain; "sincerity" is truthfulness; "simplicity" is absence of excess; "to act" is to proceed without attachment; "to respond" is to engage; "forbearance" is magnanimity and tolerance. Realizing the truth of emptiness and existence, one preserves and upholds without clinging to any extreme—thus one’s actions are simple and uncluttered. Hence it is said: Hold fast to sincerity, act with simplicity. When dwelling among others or leading the multitude, one responds with magnanimity and tolerance, overlooking others’ faults to preserve one’s own virtue. Hence it is said: Respond with forbearance. If someone comes seeking answers, one subtly gestures without resorting to verbal instruction, allowing the keen-minded to awaken instantly—thus the Dao one has realized knows no bounds. Hence it is said: Answer in silence—thus my Dao knows no end.

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to embody sincerity, simplicity, forbearance, and silence.

---

**Chapter Eighteen**
Master Guan Yin said: Plan according to affairs, decide according to principle, act through people, and succeed through Heaven. Model affairs on the present, model principles on the past; affairs align with others, but the Dao is one’s own.

When scheming for worldly matters, one judges by principle to ensure appropriateness. Hence it is said: Plan according to affairs, decide according to principle. The effort or lack thereof lies with human action, but success or failure rests with Heaven’s decree. Hence it is said: Act through people, succeed through Heaven. Model affairs on those of the present, and principles on those of the past. Hence it is said: Model affairs on the present, model principles on the past. Affairs are means—though one’s use of them may align with others, the realization of the subtle Dao, the constant stillness in response, and the untainted purity set one apart. Hence it is said: Affairs align with others, but the Dao is one’s own.

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to harmonize affairs and principles.

---

**Chapter Nineteen**
Master Guan Yin said: Gold and jade are hard to discard, while earth and stone are easy to abandon. Those who study the Dao, when encountering subtle words or wondrous deeds, must not cling to them—for they are to be practiced, not grasped. To grasp them is a malady of the heart, incurable by any medicine.

Gold and jade symbolize the words and deeds of sages, while earth and stone symbolize the words and deeds of ordinary people. Though gold and jade are precious, they become dust in the eye—the great Dao leaves no trace, and thus words and deeds cannot be equaled. Students of the Dao find it difficult to forget the words and deeds of sages, just as people find it hard to discard gold and jade. Hence it is said: Gold and jade are hard to discard. Students of the Dao easily forget the words and deeds of ordinary people, just as people readily abandon earth and stone. Hence it is said: Earth and stone are easy to abandon. When students of the Dao encounter the subtle words or wondrous deeds of sages, they must not cling to them. Hence it is said: Those who study the Dao, when encountering subtle words or wondrous deeds, must not cling to them.

chunks.original_text: 圣人之妙行，可为之而成德，而不可执着圣人妙行之U 迹也，故云是可为不可执也。 若执着之者，如人皮肤有病，容易治疗，若人病在心腹，虽卢医扁鹊，亦不能疗治，迷人执着圣人妙行之迹，亦复如是也，故云执着之者，腹心之疾，无药可疗也。 此章明治不能忘言行之病也。 右第十二章 关尹子曰：人不明於急务，而从事於多务他务奇务者，穷困灾厄及之， 急务者，道德也，多务者，万法也，他务者，傍门仗艺也，奇务者，异世之衍也。 学人不明了道德为简要急切之务，而务泥万法，或学傍门小法，或学医卜工使之艺，或学异世奇怪之衍，学虽不同，失於道德者一也，失於道德而堕轮回，动经尘劫，无有出期，此穷困灾厄莫大於是也，故云人不明於急务，而从事、於多务他务奇务者，穷困灾厄及之也。 从事者，务泥也，及之者，堕轮回也。 殊不知道无不在，不可舍此就彼。 此者，身心道德急切之务也，彼者，多务他务奇务也。 学人殊不知道无不在，即此身心是道也，既道无不在，何独身心道不在哉。 身心从道生，如涯从水生，即涯是水也，即此身心是道，亦复如是也，既悟即此身心是道，不可拾此身心，就彼多务他务奇务求道德也，故云殊不知道无不在，不可拾此就彼也。 此章明治不能以道德为务之病也。 右第二十一章 关尹子曰：天下之理，舍亲就疏，舍本就末，舍贤就愚，舍近就远，可暂而已，久则生害。 亲者，性命也，疏者，财色也，本者，道也，末者，五常百行万法也，贤者，智慧之德也，愚者，痴迷也，近者，慈善也，远者，众恶也。 天下之道理，学人迷之，拾性命道德慈善，而就泥财色万法，痴迷之众恶，可暂乐妄情，而久泥不悟，堕轮回生死，胎卯湿化，无有了期，害莫大於此也。 故云天下之理，拾亲就疏，拾本就末，拾贤就愚，拾近就远，可暂而已，久则生害也。 此章明治不悟道之病也。 右第二十二章 关尹子曰：昔之论道者，或曰凝寂，或日邃深，或日澄彻，或日空同，或日晦冥，慎勿遇此而生怖退。 凝者，定也，寂者，静也，邃者，幽也。 昔之古人论道者，或言泰定安静者，或言道幽深难穷者，或言道如水之澄彻渊奥者，或言道如虚空广大者，或言道隐晦杳冥莫测者，学人若遇此，或言凝寂、邃深、澄彻、空同、晦冥之五者，慎勿生怕怖之心，以为道之难学而退怠也。 故云昔之论道者，或日凝寂，或日邃深，或日澄彻，或日空同，或日晦冥，慎勿遇此而生怖退也。 天下至理，竟非言意，苟知非言非意在彼微言妙意之上，乃契吾说。 天下至理者，道也，竟者，终也。 向来所论之言凝寂、邃深、澄彻、空同、晦冥之五者，总属名相妄情之意识也，道本无名无情，穷究到彻尽之处，终非言意之可及也，故云天下至理，竟非言意也。 诚知非言意之可及，在彼古人微言妙意未萌之前，荐悟了然，洞彻本来见成之道，元自清净具足，不假修为外求也，如此了悟，乃契合所说之义也。 故云苟知非言非意在彼微言妙意之上，乃契吾说也。 上者，前也，苟者，诚也。 此章明治未了根尘之病也。 右第二十三章 关尹子曰：圣人大言金玉，小言桔梗芣苜，用之当，桔梗芣苜生之，不当，金玉毙之。
chunks.translated_text:
The wondrous deeds of sages may be practiced to cultivate virtue, yet one must not cling to the traces of those wondrous deeds. Hence it is said: They may be practiced but not clung to. Those who cling to them are like one whose skin bears disease—easily cured—but if the illness lies in the heart and belly, even the physicians Lu and Bian Que cannot heal it. Those who cling to the traces of sages’ wondrous deeds are likewise afflicted. Hence it is said: Those who cling to them suffer a malady of the heart and belly for which no medicine exists. This chapter cures the ailment of being unable to forget words and deeds.

**Chapter Twelve**

Master Guan Yin said: Those who fail to recognize urgent matters and instead pursue many affairs, other affairs, or strange affairs will meet with poverty, distress, and misfortune. Urgent matters are the Dao and virtue; many affairs are the ten thousand dharmas; other affairs are peripheral arts and skills; strange affairs are the heterodoxies of other worlds. If students of the Dao do not understand that the Dao and virtue are the simplest and most pressing matters, but instead become mired in the ten thousand dharmas, or study peripheral minor arts, or learn the crafts of medicine, divination, and labor, or pursue the strange heterodoxies of other worlds—though their studies differ, their loss of the Dao is one and the same. Losing the Dao, they fall into the wheel of rebirth, drifting through kalpas of dust without hope of escape. No poverty, distress, or misfortune is greater than this. Hence it is said: Those who fail to recognize urgent matters and instead pursue many affairs, other affairs, or strange affairs will meet with poverty, distress, and misfortune. "Pursue" means to become mired; "meet with" means to fall into the wheel of rebirth.

Moreover, the Dao is nowhere absent—one cannot abandon this to seek that. "This" refers to the urgent matters of the body, mind, Dao, and virtue; "that" refers to many affairs, other affairs, and strange affairs. Students of the Dao must realize that the Dao is nowhere absent, that this very body and mind are the Dao. Since the Dao is nowhere absent, how could it not reside in the body and mind? The body and mind arise from the Dao as waves arise from water—thus the waves are water, and likewise this body and mind are the Dao. Once one awakens to the truth that this body and mind are the Dao, one must not abandon them to seek the Dao in many affairs, other affairs, or strange affairs. Hence it is said: Moreover, the Dao is nowhere absent—one cannot abandon this to seek that. This chapter cures the ailment of failing to make the Dao one’s primary pursuit.

**Chapter Twenty-One**

Master Guan Yin said: Among the principles of the world, to abandon the intimate for the distant, the root for the branches, the worthy for the foolish, the near for the far—these may be tolerated briefly, but over time they bring harm. The intimate is one’s nature and life; the distant is wealth and sensuality. The root is the Dao; the branches are the five constants, the hundred practices, and the ten thousand dharmas. The worthy are the virtues of wisdom; the foolish are delusion and confusion. The near is compassion and goodness; the far is the multitude of evils.

The principles of the world lead students of the Dao astray, causing them to abandon their nature, life, Dao, virtue, compassion, and goodness, and instead become mired in wealth, sensuality, the ten thousand dharmas, delusion, and the multitude of evils. This may bring fleeting pleasure to deluded emotions, but prolonged attachment without awakening leads to the wheel of rebirth, birth and death, wombs, eggs, moisture, and transformation, without end. No harm is greater than this. Hence it is said: Among the principles of the world, to abandon the intimate for the distant, the root for the branches, the worthy for the foolish, the near for the far—these may be tolerated briefly, but over time they bring harm. This chapter cures the ailment of failing to awaken to the Dao.

**Chapter Twenty-Two**

Master Guan Yin said: Those who discoursed on the Dao in ancient times described it as concentrated stillness, profound depth, limpid clarity, vast emptiness, or obscure darkness—do not encounter such descriptions and grow fearful or retreat. "Concentrated" means settled; "stillness" means quiescent; "profound" means secluded. The ancients who discoursed on the Dao sometimes spoke of it as perfect stability and tranquility, sometimes as deep and unfathomable, sometimes as clear and abyssal like water, sometimes as vast and boundless like empty space, or sometimes as hidden, obscure, and inscrutable. If students encounter these five descriptions—concentrated stillness, profound depth, limpid clarity, vast emptiness, or obscure darkness—they must not grow fearful, thinking the Dao too difficult to study, and thus become negligent. Hence it is said: Those who discoursed on the Dao in ancient times described it as concentrated stillness, profound depth, limpid clarity, vast emptiness, or obscure darkness—do not encounter such descriptions and grow fearful or retreat.

The supreme principle of the world ultimately transcends words and concepts. If one truly knows that it is neither words nor concepts but lies beyond those subtle words and wondrous meanings, one will accord with my teaching. The supreme principle of the world is the Dao; "ultimately" means in the end. The five descriptions previously mentioned—concentrated stillness, profound depth, limpid clarity, vast emptiness, and obscure darkness—all belong to the realm of nominal appearances and deluded emotions. The Dao itself is nameless and without emotion; when thoroughly investigated to its ultimate end, it ultimately transcends words and concepts. Hence it is said: The supreme principle of the world ultimately transcends words and concepts. If one truly knows that it cannot be reached by words or concepts, and that it lies before the subtle words and wondrous meanings of the ancients, one will suddenly awaken, thoroughly perceive the originally complete and self-sufficient Dao, which is inherently pure and requires no cultivation or external seeking. Such awakening accords with the meaning of my teaching. Hence it is said: If one truly knows that it is neither words nor concepts but lies beyond those subtle words and wondrous meanings, one will accord with my teaching. "Beyond" means before; "truly" means sincerely. This chapter cures the ailment of failing to understand the roots and dusts of perception.

**Chapter Twenty-Three**

Master Guan Yin said: The great words of sages are like gold and jade; their small words are like platycodon and plantain. When used appropriately, platycodon and plantain give life; when used inappropriately, gold and jade bring death.

Students of the Dao easily forget the words and deeds of ordinary people, just as people readily abandon earth and stone. Hence it is said: Earth and stone are easy to abandon. When students of the Dao encounter the subtle words or wondrous deeds of sages, they must not cling to them. Hence it is said: Those who study the Dao, when encountering subtle words or wondrous deeds, must not cling to them.

chunks.original_text: 圣人大言者，如《道德》、《阴符》二经，如金玉之贵也，故云圣人大言金玉也。 桔梗者，草药之名也，能治风湿之疾也。 芣莒者，亦草药之名也，一名车前草，能治赤白泻痢之疾也。 小言者，如后圣诗词直言语录也。 或因诗词直言语录悟之而了道，如桔梗芣莒之草药治痊风湿痢疾，而人复安乐得活也。 故云小言桔梗芣莒，用之当，桔梗芣莒生之也。 用之当者，治痊疾也，生者，活也，或人背诵《道德》、《阴符》二经如同流水，而不能开悟了道者，如服金玉贵细之药，不能痊愈风湿泻痢之疾，以至於丧生也。 故云不当，金玉毙之也。 毙者，丧生也，不当者，不能痊疾也。 此章明治分别经言精赢之病也。 右第二十四章 关尹子曰：言某事者，甲言利，乙言害，丙言或利或害，丁言俱利俱害，必居一於此矣，喻道者不言。 某者，代称之辞也。 世人言论事理，所见不同，一人名甲，言论此事，有利益於世也，一人名乙，言论彼事，有损害於世也，故云言某事者，甲言利，乙言害也。 一人名丙，言论彼此之事，或有利益於世，或亦有害损於世也，故云丙言或利或害也。 一人名丁，言论彼此之事，行之正，俱利益於世，彼此之事，行之不正，俱害损於世也，故云丁言俱利俱害也。 甲乙丙丁四人，各论利害不同，然必有一人言之当，安於理也，故云叉居一於此矣。 居者，安也。 道本无名，不可以言比喻，在人心了悟而已，非如事有利害之比喻也，故云喻道者不言也。 此章明治未忘利害之病也。 右第二十五章 关尹子曰：事有在事言有理，道无在道言无理，知言无理，则言言皆道，不知言无理，虽执至言，为梗为医#4。 世问万事，所用各有下落，言论一事，自有一理所在也，故云事有在事言有理也。 道无处所下落，亦不属名言事理，圣人之言皆无言之言，以荐言外之旨，若了悟无言之言，不属事理，则终日言而未尝言，言言无非道也。 知者，悟也，若不悟无言之言不属事理，虽执至人之言於道眼上，如人咽喉有物梗塞，又如人眼内有尘咪障也，故云不知言无理，虽执至言，为梗为医也。 医当作翳。 此章明治未忘事理之病也。 右第二十六章 关尹子曰：不信愚人易，不信贤人难，不信贤人易，不信圣人难，不信一圣人易，不信千圣人难。 不信者，不执泥而染着也，凡愚人之言行，不执泥染着则容易，至於贤人之言行则难忘也，故云不信愚人易，不信贤人难也。 不执泥染着贤人之言行，亦容易，至於圣人之言行又难忘也，故云不信贤人易，不信圣人难也。 不执泥染着一圣人之言行，又亦容易，至於千圣人之言行尤难忘也，故云不信一圣人易，不信千圣人难也。 夫不信千圣人者，外不见人，内不见我，上不见道，下不见事。 若夫学人不执泥染着千万圣人之言行，则心忘名迹，冥然契道，而迥超几圣人我事理之名迹也，故云不慕诸圣，不重已灵，正谓此也。 故云夫不信千圣人者，外不见人，内不见我，上不见道，下不见事也。 道者，理也。 此章明治未忘凡圣之病也。 右第二十七章 关尹子曰：圣人言蒙蒙，所以使人聋，圣人言冥冥，所以使人盲，圣人言沉沉，所以使人疮。 圣人之言，尽是无言之言，令人於无言之言，荐悟言外之旨，言外之旨不属声，故学人蒙蒙然，迷情阵蔽不可得而闻之，如息聋一般也，故云圣人言蒙蒙，所以使人聋也。

**Chapter Twenty-Four**

Master Guan Yin said: The great words of sages, such as the *Dao De Jing* and the *Yin Fu Jing*, are as precious as gold and jade—hence it is said, "The great words of sages are gold and jade." Platycodon is the name of an herb that cures wind-dampness. Plantain, also called *cheqian* grass, treats red-and-white dysentery. Small words refer to later sages’ poems, lyrics, direct sayings, and recorded dialogues. If one awakens to the Dao through poems, lyrics, direct sayings, or recorded dialogues, it is like using platycodon and plantain to cure wind-dampness and dysentery, restoring health and life—hence it is said, "Small words are platycodon and plantain; when used appropriately, platycodon and plantain give life." "Used appropriately" means curing illness; "give life" means restoring vitality. Yet if one recites the *Dao De Jing* and the *Yin Fu Jing* as if flowing water but fails to awaken to the Dao, it is like taking gold and jade as medicine—unable to cure wind-dampness or dysentery, leading to death. Hence it is said, "When used inappropriately, gold and jade bring death." "Bring death" means losing life; "inappropriately" means failing to cure illness. This chapter cures the ailment of distinguishing between refined and coarse scriptural words.

**Chapter Twenty-Five**

Master Guan Yin said: When speaking of a certain matter, Person A says it is beneficial, Person B says it is harmful, Person C says it may be beneficial or harmful, and Person D says it is both beneficial and harmful—one must necessarily fall into one of these. But those who speak of the Dao do not speak. "Certain" is a placeholder term. People’s views differ when discussing matters: Person A (named *Jia*) argues that a matter benefits the world; Person B (named *Yi*) argues that another matter harms it—hence it is said, "When speaking of a certain matter, Person A says it is beneficial, Person B says it is harmful." Person C (named *Bing*) argues that a matter may benefit or harm the world—hence it is said, "Person C says it may be beneficial or harmful." Person D (named *Ding*) argues that if a matter is conducted rightly, it benefits the world, but if conducted wrongly, it harms it—hence it is said, "Person D says it is both beneficial and harmful." Though Persons A, B, C, and D differ in their judgments of benefit and harm, one of them must necessarily be correct and aligned with principle—hence it is said, "one must necessarily fall into one of these." "Fall" means to align. The Dao has no name and cannot be compared through words; it is realized only through awakening in the heart, unlike matters that can be compared in terms of benefit and harm—hence it is said, "Those who speak of the Dao do not speak." This chapter cures the ailment of failing to relinquish considerations of benefit and harm.

**Chapter Twenty-Six**

Master Guan Yin said: Matters have their place in matters, and words have their principle in words. The Dao has no place in the Dao, and words have no principle in words. One who knows that words have no principle finds every word to be the Dao; one who does not know that words have no principle, though holding the most profound words, becomes obstructed and blinded. Worldly affairs each have their proper place, and every matter discussed has its own principle—hence it is said, "Matters have their place in matters, and words have their principle in words." The Dao has no fixed place, nor does it belong to names, words, or principles. The words of sages are all wordless words, pointing to the meaning beyond words. If one awakens to the wordless words, realizing they do not belong to matters or principles, then though one speaks all day, one has never truly spoken, and every word is the Dao. "Knows" means awakens. If one does not awaken to the wordless words that transcend matters and principles, though holding the words of the most realized ones before the eye of the Dao, it is like an obstruction in the throat or dust in the eye—hence it is said, "One who does not know that words have no principle, though holding the most profound words, becomes obstructed and blinded." *Yi* should be *yi* (blindness). This chapter cures the ailment of failing to relinquish attachment to matters and principles.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven**

Master Guan Yin said: It is easy not to trust foolish people, but difficult not to trust worthy ones. It is easy not to trust worthy people, but difficult not to trust sages. It is easy not to trust one sage, but difficult not to trust a thousand sages. "Not to trust" means not to cling or become attached. The words and deeds of foolish people are easily relinquished without attachment, but those of worthy people are harder to forget—hence it is said, "It is easy not to trust foolish people, but difficult not to trust worthy ones." It is also easy to relinquish attachment to the words and deeds of worthy people, but those of sages are harder to forget—hence it is said, "It is easy not to trust worthy people, but difficult not to trust sages." It is also easy to relinquish attachment to the words and deeds of one sage, but those of a thousand sages are even harder to forget—hence it is said, "It is easy not to trust one sage, but difficult not to trust a thousand sages." One who does not trust a thousand sages sees neither others nor self, neither the Dao above nor matters below. If a learner does not cling to the words and deeds of a thousand sages, the mind forgets names and traces, merging obscurely with the Dao, transcending the distinctions of sages, self, matters, and principles—hence it is said, "Not admiring the many sages, not valuing one’s own spirit" refers precisely to this. Thus it is said, "One who does not trust a thousand sages sees neither others nor self, neither the Dao above nor matters below." The Dao is principle. This chapter cures the ailment of failing to relinquish attachment to the ordinary and the sagely.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight**

Master Guan Yin said: The words of sages are dim and hazy, thereby making people deaf. The words of sages are dark and obscure, thereby making people blind. The words of sages are deep and heavy, thereby making people wounded. The words of sages are all wordless words, leading people to awaken to the meaning beyond words. This meaning beyond words does not belong to sound, so learners become dim and confused, their deluded feelings veiling them—unable to hear it, as if struck deaf. Hence it is said, "The words of sages are dim and hazy, thereby making people deaf."

chunks.original_text: 言外之旨不属於色，杳杳冥冥，视之不见，令人如息盲病一般也，故云圣人言冥冥，所以使人盲也。 言外之旨不属於名，况况静静，言之难议，令人如息瘠痉之病也，故云圣人言沉况，所以使人瘠也。 惟聋则不闻声，惟盲则不见色，惟疮则不音言。 惟息耳聋之病者，则於声无所闻也，故云惟聋则不闻声也。 惟息目盲之病者，则於色无所见也，故云惟盲则不见色也。 惟息疳痉之病者，则於声无所言也，故云惟瘠则不音言也。 不闻声者，不闻道、不闻事、不闻我，不见色者，不见道、不见事、不见我，不音言者，不言道、不言事、不言我。 言外之旨，既听之不闻其声，未若如息耳聋，亦不闻道、事、我三者之声也，故云不闻声者，不闻道，不闻事，不闻我也。 言外之旨既视之不见其色，未若如息眼盲，亦不见道、事、我三者之色也，亦不生此见解也，故云不见色者，不见道，不见事，不见我也。 言外之旨既议之无名，未若息瘠痉不能言者，亦不言道、事、我三者之名也，故云不音言者，不言道，不言事，不言我也。 此章明治未忘色声名道事我之病也。 右第二十八章 关尹子曰：人徒知伪得之中有真失，殊不知真得之中有真失，徒知伪是之中有真非，殊不知真是之中有真非。 学人护知认着妄得以为诚失於至道，殊不知真得之见，亦诚失於至道也，如金屑虽实，入眼则为尘翳也，故云人徒知伪得之中有真失，殊不知真得之中有真失也。 伪者，妄也，真者，诚也，徒者，馒也。 学人谈知认着妄是以为诚非，殊不知认着真是亦为诚非也，故云徒知伪是之中有真非，殊不知真是之中有真非也。 此章明治未忘真假之病也。 右第二十九章 关尹子曰：言道者如言梦，夫言梦者曰：如此金玉，如此器皿，如此禽兽，言者能言之，不能取而与之，听者能闻之，不能受而得之，惟善听者，不泥不辩。 大悟大彻之士，如人睡梦觉来，方知梦中所见之境，皆是妄想颠倒识见之所成也，未能大悟大彻之士，以识见能通万法，为人谈演妙道，皆是梦中说梦也，故云言道者如言梦也。 梦中说梦曰：梦见如此金宝大山，巍峨无量，如此玉洞，广阔幽深难测，此二者喻以道德为灵宝洞玄，广大幽深无量难测也，故云夫言梦者日，如此金玉也。 又梦中说梦日，梦见如此玉器金皿，使用无数，此喻建立妙用，普利众善万行也，故云如此器皿也。 又梦中说梦日，如此乌兔龟凤龙虎，此喻金乌玉兔，乌龟赤凤，白虎青龙，阴阳造化也，故云如此禽兽也。 梦中说梦见此金玉器皿禽兽，说者但能说之，不能取金玉器皿禽兽与听说之人也，此喻圣人不能出道以示与学人也，故云言者能言之，不能取而与之也。 梦中听说梦境之人，但闻说如此金玉器皿禽兽，不能承受取得之也，此喻学道者因师方便点化，言下自悟不从外得＇也，故云听者能闻之，不能受而得之也。 惟有利根者善闻道德玄妙，不执泥荃蹄，不辫论圣人无言之言，但因圣人无言之言，荐悟言外之旨，了悟不可思议之道也，故云惟善听者，不泥不辫也。 此章明治未悟谈道之病也。 右第三十章
chunks.translated_text:
The meaning beyond words does not pertain to form—dim and obscure, invisible when gazed upon, leaving people as if afflicted with blindness. Hence it is said, "The words of sages are dark and obscure, thereby making people blind."

The meaning beyond words does not pertain to names—profound and still, difficult to discuss in speech, leaving people as if stricken with emaciation and spasms. Hence it is said, "The words of sages are deep and heavy, thereby making people wounded."

Only the deaf do not hear sound; only the blind do not see form; only the wounded do not utter speech.

Only those afflicted with deafness cannot hear sound—thus it is said, "Only the deaf do not hear sound." Only those afflicted with blindness cannot see form—thus it is said, "Only the blind do not see form." Only those afflicted with emaciation and spasms cannot speak—thus it is said, "Only the wounded do not utter speech."

Those who do not hear sound do not hear the Dao, do not hear matters, do not hear the self. Those who do not see form do not see the Dao, do not see matters, do not see the self. Those who do not utter speech do not speak of the Dao, do not speak of matters, do not speak of the self.

The meaning beyond words, though inaudible when listened to, is not unlike the deaf who also cannot hear the sounds of the Dao, matters, or the self. Hence it is said, "Those who do not hear sound do not hear the Dao, do not hear matters, do not hear the self." The meaning beyond words, though invisible when gazed upon, is not unlike the blind who also cannot see the forms of the Dao, matters, or the self, nor do they generate such perceptions. Hence it is said, "Those who do not see form do not see the Dao, do not see matters, do not see the self." The meaning beyond words, though indescribable in speech, is not unlike those afflicted with emaciation and spasms who cannot speak—nor can they name the Dao, matters, or the self. Hence it is said, "Those who do not utter speech do not speak of the Dao, do not speak of matters, do not speak of the self."

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to relinquish attachment to form, sound, names, the Dao, matters, and the self.

**Chapter Twenty-Nine**

Master Guan Yin said: People merely recognize that within false attainment lies true loss, yet fail to see that within true attainment lies true loss. They merely recognize that within false affirmation lies true negation, yet fail to see that within true affirmation lies true negation.

Learners cling to deluded attainment, mistaking it for genuine loss in the supreme Dao, unaware that even true attainment is a genuine loss in the supreme Dao—just as gold dust, though real, becomes an obstruction when it enters the eye. Hence it is said, "People merely recognize that within false attainment lies true loss, yet fail to see that within true attainment lies true loss."

The false is illusion; the true is sincerity; "merely" denotes ignorance.

Learners discuss knowledge, clinging to deluded affirmation as if it were genuine negation, unaware that clinging to true affirmation is also genuine negation. Hence it is said, "They merely recognize that within false affirmation lies true negation, yet fail to see that within true affirmation lies true negation."

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to relinquish attachment to the real and the illusory.

**Chapter Thirty**

Master Guan Yin said: Speaking of the Dao is like speaking of dreams. Those who speak of dreams say: such gold and jade, such vessels, such birds and beasts. The speaker can describe them but cannot take and give them; the listener can hear but cannot receive and obtain them. Only the adept listener neither clings nor disputes.

Those of great awakening and thorough comprehension are like one who awakens from a dream, only then realizing that all perceived within the dream was the fabrication of deluded, inverted perceptions. Those who have not attained great awakening and thorough comprehension, though their perceptions may comprehend all phenomena, expound the wondrous Dao to others—all is but dreaming within a dream. Hence it is said, "Speaking of the Dao is like speaking of dreams."

Speaking of dreams within a dream, one says: I dreamed of such golden treasures and towering mountains, vast and immeasurable; such jade caverns, boundless and profoundly deep. These two metaphors illustrate the Dao and virtue as numinous treasures and mysterious caverns—vast, profound, immeasurable, and unfathomable. Hence it is said, "Those who speak of dreams say: such gold and jade."

Again, speaking of dreams within a dream, one says: I dreamed of such jade vessels and golden utensils, countless in their use. This metaphor illustrates the establishment of wondrous functions, universally benefiting all virtuous practices. Hence it is said, "Such vessels."

Again, speaking of dreams within a dream, one says: I dreamed of such crows and hares, tortoises and phoenixes, dragons and tigers. This metaphor illustrates the golden crow and jade hare, the black tortoise and vermilion phoenix, the white tiger and azure dragon—yin and yang in transformation. Hence it is said, "Such birds and beasts."

Speaking of dreams within a dream, one describes such gold, jade, vessels, birds, and beasts, yet the speaker can only describe them and cannot take the gold, jade, vessels, birds, or beasts to give to the listener. This metaphor illustrates that the sage cannot manifest the Dao to present to the learner. Hence it is said, "The speaker can describe them but cannot take and give them."

Those who listen to the dream within a dream only hear of such gold, jade, vessels, birds, and beasts but cannot receive or obtain them. This metaphor illustrates that those who study the Dao, through the master’s skillful guidance, awaken in an instant—not obtaining from without. Hence it is said, "The listener can hear but cannot receive and obtain them."

Only those of keen faculties, adept at hearing the profound and wondrous Dao, neither cling to words nor dispute the sage’s wordless speech. They merely, through the sage’s wordless speech, awaken to the meaning beyond words, realizing the inconceivable Dao. Hence it is said, "Only the adept listener neither clings nor disputes."

This chapter cures the ailment of failing to awaken from the affliction of discoursing on the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 关尹子曰：圆尔道，方尔德，平尔行，锐尔事。 尔者，学道之人也。 天下学道之人，但能详读审诵九篇，精之研之，究之彻之，自然了悟不可思议之至道，人人具足，个个圆成，不假修为，位齐诸圣也，故云圆尔道也。 方者，正也，德者，道之用也。 天下学道之人，若因经了悟不可思议之至道，仍要护持保任也。 如何护持保任？ 但能以无为清净，逍遥自在，不染不着护其内，以谦卑柔弱，不与物争护其外，次又正其妙用，用之於众，善利物安人，不求报恩，皆为用之正，而成上德也，故云方尔德也。 天下学人，若因经了悟不可思议之至道，护持保任，要成上德，须是自利利他，平等普惠，不择贵贱贫富，男女妍丑，仁慈等利，无偏无党，以成万德之妙行也，故云平尔行也。 锐者，利也，事者，用也。 天下学人，因经了悟不可思议真空妙有之道，以为真心之体，以至德妙行为真心之用，自利利他，於事无往不利也，故云锐尔事也。 此章尹君自迷一经之旨趣也。 右第三十一章 文始真经注卷之九竟

Lord Guan Yinzi said: Let your Dao be round, your virtue square, your conduct level, and your affairs sharp.

"You" refers to those who study the Dao. Among all who study the Dao in the world, if they can but read carefully and recite thoroughly these nine chapters, refining and delving into them, investigating and penetrating them, they will naturally awaken to the inconceivable Supreme Dao—each person possessing it in full, every individual perfected in its completeness, without need of cultivation or effort, their station equal to that of all sages. Hence it is said, "Let your Dao be round."

"Square" means upright; "virtue" is the function of the Dao. Among all who study the Dao in the world, if through the scripture they awaken to the inconceivable Supreme Dao, they must still safeguard, uphold, and preserve it. How to safeguard, uphold, and preserve it? Simply by maintaining non-action and purity, wandering carefree and at ease, neither clinging nor attaching to guard within; by humility and gentleness, not contending with things to guard without. Furthermore, rectify its wondrous function, applying it among the multitude, benefiting beings and pacifying people without seeking repayment or gratitude—all this is the upright application of it, thereby perfecting the highest virtue. Hence it is said, "Let your virtue be square."

Among all students of the Dao in the world, if through the scripture they awaken to the inconceivable Supreme Dao and safeguard, uphold, and preserve it to perfect the highest virtue, they must benefit themselves and others equally, bestowing universal kindness without distinction of noble or base, poor or rich, male or female, beauty or ugliness. With impartial benevolence and no favoritism, they perfect the wondrous conduct of the ten thousand virtues. Hence it is said, "Let your conduct be level."

"Sharp" means keen; "affairs" means function. Among all students of the Dao in the world, if through the scripture they awaken to the inconceivable Dao of True Emptiness and Wondrous Being, taking it as the essence of the true mind and the highest virtue and wondrous conduct as the function of the true mind, then in benefiting themselves and others, they will be keen in all affairs. Hence it is said, "Let your affairs be sharp."

This chapter elucidates the intent of the entire scripture as understood by Master Yin. Here ends the ninth scroll of the *Commentary on the Wenshi Zhenjing*.

**Postface to the *Wenshi Zhenjing***
Composed by Ge Xianweng of the Jin

Though my form be as humble as mugwort or wormwood, I have by chance come to cherish the longevity of towering pines. Those who know the Dao, though lowly, must be embraced; though barbarian, must be esteemed.

Later, I encountered Master Zheng Siyuan. Master Zheng possessed many books of jade tablets and jasper bamboo slips. Through elixirs and herbs, he opened for me the finest medicines of the supreme Dao; through breath and absorption, he cleansed me with the purest flavors of Purple Clarity. Later, he entrusted me with the nine scrolls of the Perfected Yin’s *Wenshi Jing*. I cherished them, recited them, treasured them, and revered them.

The *Yu* is the Dao; the *Zhu* establishes heaven and earth; the *Ji* honors the Dark Man; the *Fu* is the spirit, soul, ethereal and corporeal souls; the *Jian* is the heart; the *Bi* is food; the *Fu* is transformation; the *Chou* is things; the *Yao* is compounded remedies.

With each savoring, I grew as light as treading upon a drifting leaf, roaming the undifferentiated vastness of heaven and earth; as boundless as striding a staff across the horizon, afloat upon the fathomless expanse of the great sea. Lofty as dwelling in halls of gold, jade, and precious stones; solemn as wielding the seal of ghosts, demons, and treacherous spirits. Swift as soaring phoenixes and cranes; fierce as battling tigers and rhinoceroses. Pure as bathing in azure waters; somber as dreaming of crimson hues. Seizing and releasing the great Dao, merging with the primal principle—such depths are beyond the reach of alchemists, unspoken by earlier scholars. It may be looked up to but not scaled; admired but not grasped; mirrored but not pondered; aligned with but not expressed. Is this not the discourse of those who forget things and forsake the world? The words of those who sever ties and abandon cunning? The speech of those who harmonize with yin and yang, obscuring self and other?

How exalted! How vast! And yet—how simple and effortless!

I received this teaching firsthand.
